title: Expressing Cause/Reason (~니까/아서/어서/으니)
short_explanation: Used to express the reason or cause; 'because', 'since'.
long_explanation: In Korean, various grammatical patterns such as ~니까, ~아서/어서, and ~으니 are used to indicate the cause or reason for an action or situation. They are equivalent to 'because' or 'since' in English and are used to logically connect two clauses. They can be used in both positive and negative contexts.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 열심히 공부하니까 TOPIK 시험을 쉽게 패스할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang yeolsimhi gongbuhani TOPIK siheomeul swipge paeseuhal geot gatayo.
examples.en: Because he always studies hard, I think he will easily pass the TOPIK exam.

examples.kr: 여행을 가고 싶었는데, 돈이 없어서 가지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengeul gago sip-eossneunde, don-i eobseoseo gaji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I wanted to travel, but I couldn't go because I didn't have money.

examples.kr: 그는 병가를 냈으니 회사에 안 왔네요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun byonggareul naesseuni hoesa-e an watneyo.
examples.en: He didn't come to the office because he took a sick leave.

examples.kr: 비가 내려서 외출을 취소했어요.
examples.romaji: Bi-ga naeryeoseo oechureul chwisohaesseoyo.
examples.en: I cancelled going out because it was raining.

title: ~남짓 [namjit] (About, or so)
short_explanation: Used to mean 'about' or 'approximately' when expressing quantities, amounts, or time.
long_explanation: ~남짓 is a Korean grammar point used to indicate an approximate amount, quantity, or duration. It is equivalent to 'about' or 'approximately' in English and is used when providing an estimation rather than an exact figure.

examples.kr: 제가 이 책을 읽는데 일주일 남짓 걸렸어요.
examples.romaji: Jega i chaeg-eul ilgneunde ilju-il namjit geollyeosseoyo.
examples.en: It took me about a week to read this book.

examples.kr: 이번 여행에 10만원 남짓 썼어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon yeohaeng-e 10manwon namjit sseosseoyo.
examples.en: On this trip, I spent about 100,000 won.

examples.kr: 아이들이 학교에 도착하기까지 10분 남짓 걸린 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Aideuli hakgyo-e dochak-hagikkaji 10bun namjit geollin geos gatayo.
examples.en: I think it took the children about 10 minutes to get to school.

examples.kr: 회사에서 집까지 걸어서 한 시간 남짓 걸려요.
examples.romaji: Hoesa-eseo jipkkaji georeoseo han shigan namjit geollyeoyo.
examples.en: It takes about an hour to walk from the office to home.

title: ~내내 [naenae] (Throughout, the whole time)
short_explanation: Used to express something that continues throughout a specific period of time.
long_explanation: ~내내 is a compound particle that indicates an action or situation lasted for the entire duration of a specific period. It emphasizes continuity.

examples.kr: 학교에서는 수업 내내 선생님의 설명을 들어야 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoeseoneun sueop naenae seonsaengnimui seolmyeongeul deuryeoya haetsseumnida.
examples.en: At school, we had to listen to the teacher's explanation throughout the class.

examples.kr: 그 날은 비가 내내 와서 우산 없이는 나갈 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Geu nareun biga naenae waseo usan eobsineun nagal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: It rained all day that day, so you couldn't go out without an umbrella.

examples.kr: 여름 휴가에서 우리는 바닷가에서 하루 내내 놀았습니다.
examples.romaji: Yeoreum hyugaseo urineun badatgaeseo haru naenae nolassseumnida.
examples.en: During our summer vacation, we played at the beach all day.

examples.kr: 그의 결혼식에서 그는 밤 내내 춤을 추었습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuui gyeolhonsigeseo geuneun bam naenae chumeul chueossseumnida.
examples.en: At his wedding, he danced all night long.

title: ~네요 [neyo] (Expressing surprise)
short_explanation: Used to express surprise, new realizations, or sudden changes.
long_explanation: ~네요 is added to the stem of a verb or adjective to convey the speaker's surprise, realization, or a sudden change in circumstances. It expresses the speaker's impression or sentiment about a situation.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 정말 좋네요, 햇볕이 따뜻해서 기분이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga jeongmal johneyo, haetbyeoti ttatteutaseo gibuni johajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The weather is really nice today, and the warm sunlight lifted my mood.

examples.kr: 이 케이크가 너무 맛있네요, 나는 이번에 처음으로 이 케이크를 먹어봤어요.
examples.romaji: I keikeuga neomu masinneoyo, naneun ibeon-e cheoeumeuro i keikeureul meogeobwasseoyo.
examples.en: This cake is very delicious; it's my first time trying it.

examples.kr: 우리 아이가 너무 빨리 크네요, 이렇게 커지면서 많은 것을 배우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri aiga neomu ppalli keuneyo, ireoke keojimyeon maneun geoseul baeugo isseoyo.
examples.en: Our child is growing up so fast, learning a lot as he grows.

examples.kr: 갑자기 비가 오네요, 우산을 가져오지 않아서 비를 피할 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Gapjagi biga oneyo, usan-eul gajyeoji anhaseo bireul pihal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: It's suddenly raining, and I couldn't avoid it because I didn't bring an umbrella.

title: ~노릇이다 [noreusida] (Act as, function as)
short_explanation: Used to describe someone or something acting or functioning as another role or duty.
long_explanation: ~노릇이다 is used when someone or something takes on a role or duty that is not their primary one, often unexpectedly or due to circumstances. It carries the nuance of having to assume responsibilities not originally one's own.

examples.kr: 오늘은 선생님이 아프셔서 제가 선생님 노릇이 될 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun seonsaengnimi apeusyeoseo jega seonsaengnim noreusida doel geosibnida.
examples.en: Since the teacher is sick today, I will act as the teacher.

examples.kr: 아빠가 출장 갔으니 엄마가 아빠 노릇이다.
examples.romaji: Appa-ga chuljang gatseuni, eomma-ga appa noreusida.
examples.en: Since Dad is on a business trip, Mom will act as Dad.

examples.kr: 이 잡지는 여행 가이드 노릇을 합니다.
examples.romaji: I jabjineun yeohaeng gideu noreuseul hamnida.
examples.en: This magazine serves as a travel guide.

examples.kr: 그녀는 친구보다는 언니 노릇을 해주는 게 좋다고 생각해.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun chingubodaneun unni noreul haejuneun ge jotago saenggakhae.
examples.en: She thinks it's better for her to act as an older sister than just a friend.

title: ~느라고 [neurago] (Because of being occupied with)
short_explanation: Used to express that someone is so busy with one action that it prevents or hinders another, often resulting in a negative consequence.
long_explanation: ~느라고 is used to indicate that an action or situation is taking up so much time or energy that it results in an undesired consequence, such as neglecting another activity. It expresses a cause-effect relationship with a sense of regret or inconvenience.

examples.kr: 저는 토픽 시험을 준비하느라고 새벽까지 공부했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun TOPIK siheomeul junbihaneurago saebyeokkkaji gongbuhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I studied until dawn because I was busy preparing for the TOPIK exam.

examples.kr: 우리는 프로젝트를 마치느라고 이틀 동안 잠을 거의 안 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun peurojekteureul machineurago iteul dongan jameul geoui an jasseoyo.
examples.en: We hardly slept for two days because we were busy finishing the project.

examples.kr: 그는 대회 준비하느라고 식사를 거렀어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun daehoe junbi haneurago siksareul georeossoyo.
examples.en: He skipped meals because he was busy preparing for the competition.

examples.kr: 어머니는 저를 대학교에 보내느라 밤늦게까지 일하셨어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jeoreul daehagyoe bonaenura bam neutgekkaji ilhaesyeosseoyo.
examples.en: My mother worked late into the night because she had to send me to college.

title: ~는데다가 [neundedaga] (Moreover, furthermore)
short_explanation: Used to add additional information or to emphasize a point; 'moreover', 'furthermore'.
long_explanation: ~는데다가 is a conjunctive expression used to add extra information or emphasize a detail in a sentence. It builds on previous statements by providing another reason or detail.

examples.kr: 그의 성적이 우수한데다가, 운동 능력도 탁월해요.
examples.romaji: Geuui seongjeogi usuhandeundaga, undong neungnyeokdo takweolhaeyo.
examples.en: Moreover, his grades are excellent, and his athletic ability is outstanding.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 몸이 안 좋은데다가, 날씨도 매우 춥네요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul momi an joheundeda, nalssido maeu chubneyo.
examples.en: I'm not feeling well today, and moreover, the weather is very cold.

examples.kr: 그 카페는 분위기도 좋은데다가, 커피의 맛도 훌륭하네요.
examples.romaji: Geu kape-neun bunwigido joheundaga, keopiui matdo hullyunghaneyo.
examples.en: That cafe has a great atmosphere, and moreover, the taste of the coffee is excellent.

examples.kr: 안목이 넓은 게 장점인데다가, 한국어도 잘하네요.
examples.romaji: Anmok-i neolbeun ge jangjeomindeundaga, Hanguk-eo do jalhaneyo.
examples.en: Having a broad taste is a plus, and moreover, she speaks Korean well.

title: ~는측에서 [neuncheugeseo] (From the perspective of)
short_explanation: Used to express 'from the standpoint of' or 'from the perspective of'.
long_explanation: The suffix ~는측에서 is used to indicate a particular viewpoint or perspective from which something is evaluated or observed. It is often used to present opinions or judgments from a specific standpoint.

examples.kr: 학생들의 측에서 볼 때, 과제가 너무 많아서 부담스럽다.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeul-ui cheug-eseo bol ttae, gwaje-ga neomu manh-aseo budamseureopda.
examples.en: From the students' perspective, the amount of homework is too much and burdensome.

examples.kr: 경제학자의 측에서 디지털 화폐는 실제 경제에 큰 영향을 미칠 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Gyeongje-hakja-ui cheug-eseo dijiteol hwapyeneun silje gyeongje-e keun yeonghyangeul michil su itsseumnida.
examples.en: From an economist's perspective, digital currencies can have a big impact on the real economy.

examples.kr: 의사의 측에서 본다면 치킨은 건강에 해로울 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Uisa-ui cheug-eseo bondamyeon, chikin-eun geongang-e haeroul su itsseumnida.
examples.en: From a doctor's perspective, chicken can be harmful to your health.

examples.kr: 엄마의 측에서 본다면, 자기 아이가 항상 제일이에요.
examples.romaji: Eomma-ui cheug-eseo bondamyeon, jagi ai-ga hangsang jeilieyo.
examples.en: From a mother's perspective, her child is always the best.

title: ~더라도 [deorado] (Even if, even though)
short_explanation: Used to express a conditional statement meaning 'even if' or 'even though'.
long_explanation: The pattern ~더라도 is used to present a condition that might be contrary to what is expected. It indicates that even if a certain condition holds, the outcome remains unchanged or is unsatisfactory.

examples.kr: 당신이 얼마나 시간을 많이 투자하더라도 그 결과가 만족스럽지 않으면 어떤가요?
examples.romaji: Dangsini eolmana siganeul mani tujahadeorago geu gyeolgwa-ga manjogseureopji anheumyeon eotteongayo?
examples.en: What if you invest a lot of time, but the result is not satisfactory?

examples.kr: 나는 하루 종일 공부하더라도 시험에 떨어지면 내 노력이 무용지물이 되어버릴 거야.
examples.romaji: Naneun haru jongil gongbuhadeorago siheome tteoreojimyeon nae noryeogi muyongjimurie do-eobeoril geoya.
examples.en: Even if I study all day, if I fail the exam, my efforts will be wasted.

examples.kr: 네가 얼마나 노력하더라도 그 목표를 이루지 못하면 어떨까요?
examples.romaji: Nega eolmana noryeokhadeorago geu mokpyoreul iruji mothamyeon eotteolkka yo?
examples.en: What if you work hard, but fail to achieve your goal?

examples.kr: 나는 얼마나 일해도 돈이 모이지 않으면 힘들어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eolmana ilhaedo don-i moi ji anheumyeon himdeureoyo.
examples.en: It's tough if I work so much and money doesn't accumulate.

title: ~다니 [dani] (Expressing disbelief)
short_explanation: Used to express surprise, doubt, or disbelief regarding a particular situation or piece of information.
long_explanation: ~다니 is attached to the end of a sentence or clause to convey the speaker's disbelief, shock, or doubt about something they have just heard or observed.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지가 내일 급하게 해외로 떠난다니 전혀 믿을 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojiga naeil geuphage haeoero tteonandani jeonhyeo mideul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I can't believe that my father is leaving for overseas in a hurry tomorrow.

examples.kr: 너가 진짜로 이렇게 어려운 문제를 해결했다니 정말 놀랍습니다.
examples.romaji: Neoga jinjjaro ireohge eoryeoun munjereul haegyeolhaetdani jeongmal nollapseubnida.
examples.en: I'm really amazed that you actually solved such a difficult problem.

examples.kr: 원래 계획이 달라질 건데, 그가 이 팀의 리더가 될 거라니 믿기지 않아.
examples.romaji: Wonrae gyehoegi dallajil geonde, geuga i tim-ui rideoga doel georani midgiji ana.
examples.en: The original plan was to change, but I can't believe that he's going to be the leader of this team.

examples.kr: 많은 사람들이 기대하고 있었는데, 공연이 취소되다니 아쉽다.
examples.romaji: Manheun saramdeuli gidaehago isseonneunde, gongyeoni chwisodoedani aswipda.
examples.en: A lot of people were looking forward to it, but it's a shame that the performance was canceled.

title: ~답게 [dapge] (As befitting, like)
short_explanation: Used to express the meaning of 'as befitting' or 'like', highlighting the natural or expected characteristic or behavior of someone or something.
long_explanation: The '~답게' pattern follows a noun to mean 'as is fitting for' or 'in a manner characteristic of'. It emphasizes the inherent qualities or typical behavior one would expect, and is used to comment on the natural characteristics of people or things.

examples.kr: 프로 축구 선수답게, 그는 공을 능숙하게 다루는 법을 잘 알고 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Peuro chukgu seonsudapge, geuneun gongeul neungsukhage daruneun beob-eul jal algo isseotseumnida.
examples.en: As befitting a professional soccer player, he knew well how to handle the ball skillfully.

examples.kr: 공부하는 학생답게, 그는 수학 문제를 쉽게 해결할 수 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhaneun haksaengdapge, geuneun suhak munjereul swipge haegyeolhal su isseotseumnida.
examples.en: As befitting a diligent student, he was able to easily solve math problems.

examples.kr: 명품 디자이너답게, 그녀의 옷은 각 세부 사항이 완벽하게 만들어졌습니다.
examples.romaji: Myeongpum dijaineodapge, geunyeoui oseun gak sebu sahangi wanbyeokhage mandeureojyeotseumnida.
examples.en: As befitting a luxury designer, her clothes were crafted perfectly in every detail.

examples.kr: 경험 있는 요리사답게, 그는 요리 재료를 빠르게 다룰 수 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Gyeongheom inneun yorisadapge, geuneun yori jaryoreul ppareuge darul su isseotseumnida.
examples.en: As befitting an experienced chef, he was able to handle cooking ingredients quickly.

title: ~대로 [daero] (As per, following)
short_explanation: Used to express doing something in accordance with or following something else.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~대로' is used when an action is performed exactly as indicated by a rule, instruction, or example. It is similar to the English expressions 'as per', 'according to', or 'following'.

examples.kr: 매일 운동하라는 지시대로 매일 아침 운동을 하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Maeil undongharaneun jishidaero maeil achim undongeul hago itsseumnida.
examples.en: As per the instruction to exercise every day, I work out every morning.

examples.kr: 매뉴얼에 적힌 대로, 기계를 작동시켜야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Maenyueol-e jeokhin daero, gigyereul jakdongsikyeoya hamnida.
examples.en: According to the manual, you should operate the machine.

examples.kr: 엄마가 말한 대로 공부를 열심히 했고, 그래서 성적이 좋았습니다.
examples.romaji: Eommaga malhan daero, gongbureul yeolsimhi haetgo, geuraeseo seongjeogi jotseumnida.
examples.en: I studied hard as my mom instructed, and consequently my grades were good.

examples.kr: 건물의 모든 창문은 설계도대로 완벽하게 설치되었습니다.
examples.romaji: Geonmul-ui modeun changmun-eun seolgyedodaero wanbyeokhage seolchidoeeotseumnida.
examples.en: All the windows of the building were installed perfectly according to the blueprint.

title: ~던데 [deonde] (Used to, before)
short_explanation: Used to express that something was the case or happened in the past, often to introduce contrasting or unexpected information.
long_explanation: The '~던데' pattern is attached to a verb to indicate that something used to happen or be the case, often implying a change or contrast with the present. It is used to recall past conditions or behaviors and can be translated as 'used to' or 'before'.

examples.kr: 우리 철수가 말하던데, 그는 학교에서 항상 열심히 공부하던 학생이었다고 해.
examples.romaji: Uri Cheolsuga malhadeon de, geuneun hakgyoeseo hangsang yeolsimhi gongbuhadeon haksaengieotdago hae.
examples.en: Cheolsu was saying that he used to be a student who always studied diligently at school.

examples.kr: 그 레스토랑은 맛있는 음식을 팔던데, 최근에는 그렇지 않아.
examples.romaji: Geu reseutorangeun masinneun eumsigeul paldeonde, choegeuneun geureohji anha.
examples.en: That restaurant used to serve delicious food, but it doesn't anymore.

examples.kr: 아빠는 전에 매일 아침에 운동하던데, 요즘은 그렇지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Appa-neun jeone maeil achime undonghadeon de, yojeumeun geureohji anhayo.
examples.en: Dad used to exercise every morning, but he doesn't these days.

examples.kr: 첫 만남에서 그는 매우 친절하던데, 하지만 이제는 그렇지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Cheot manname, geuneun maeu chinjeolhadeon de, hajiman ijeneun geureohji anhayo.
examples.en: He was very kind when we first met, but not anymore.

title: ~도록 하다 [dorok hada] (Make sure that, ensure that)
short_explanation: Used to express a commitment or directive to make sure that something happens.
long_explanation: The '~도록 하다' construction is used to indicate that the speaker intends to make something occur or wants someone to ensure a specific result. It is similar to saying 'make sure that' or 'ensure that' in English.

examples.kr: 제가 이 일을 해결하도록 하겠습니다, 걱정하지 마세요.
examples.romaji: Jega i ireul haegyeolhadorok hagessseumnida, geokjeonghaji maseyo.
examples.en: I will make sure to resolve this issue, so don't worry.

examples.kr: 고객이 만족할 수 있도록 최선을 다하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Gogaegi manjokhal su itdorok choeseoneul dahagessseumnida.
examples.en: We will do our best to ensure customer satisfaction.

examples.kr: 아이들이 안전하게 학교에 도착할 수 있도록 운전을 천천히하세요.
examples.romaji: Aideuri anjeonhage hakgyoe dochakhal su itdorok unjeoneul cheoncheonhi haseyo.
examples.en: Drive slowly to make sure that the children arrive at school safely.

examples.kr: 모두가 잘 이해할 수 있도록 천천히 말하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Moduga jal ihaehal su itdorok cheoncheonhi malhagessseumnida.
examples.en: I will speak slowly to ensure that everyone understands well.

title: ~라든지 ~라든지 [radenji radenji] (Either or)
short_explanation: Used to list alternative options or possibilities without specifying a single choice.
long_explanation: The '~라든지 ~라든지' pattern is used to list alternative options or possibilities, implying that any one of the mentioned items could be chosen. It is similar to 'either or' in English, used when the speaker does not wish to specify a particular option.

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에는 피자라든지 치킨라든지 뭐든지 주문해 먹을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeogeneun pizaradenji chikinradenji mweodenji jumunhae meogeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: For dinner tonight, I'll order something—maybe pizza, chicken, or whatever.

examples.kr: 당신이 필요로 하는 것이 뭐든지, 컴퓨터라든지 책이라든지, 저는 준비할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-i pilyoro haneun geosi mwo deunji, keompyuteoradenji chaeradenji, jeoneun junbi hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Whatever you need—be it a computer or a book—I can prepare it.

examples.kr: 운동하러 갈까 생각 중인데, 달리기라든지 수영이라든지 뭐라든지 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Undong hareo galkka saenggak junginde, dalligiradenji suyeongradenji mweodenji joayo.
examples.en: I'm thinking of going exercise—maybe running, swimming, or something else would be fine.

examples.kr: 1위를 차지할 수 있는 사람은 당신이라든지 누군가 될 거예요.
examples.romaji: Ilwireul chaji hal su inneun saram-eun dangsinradenji nugungga doel geoyeyo.
examples.en: The person who can take first place will either be you or someone else.

title: ~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada] (Try to)
short_explanation: Used to express an intention or plan to do something.
long_explanation: The '~려고 하다' structure is commonly used to indicate that someone intends, plans, or attempts to do something. It is equivalent to the English phrases 'plan to', 'intend to', or 'try to'.

examples.kr: 요즘 한국어를 배우려고 하다 보니까 하루가 어떻게 지나가는지도 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum hangug-eoreul baeworyeogo hada bonikka, haruga eotteohge jinaganeunji moleugess-eoyo.
examples.en: These days, as I'm trying to learn Korean, I don't even notice how quickly the day passes.

examples.kr: 내일 친구를 만나려고 해서 지금은 너무 먼저 자려고 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil chingureul mannalyeogo haeseo, jigeumeun neomu meonjeo jalyeogo hago isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm trying to sleep early now because I'm planning to meet a friend tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그는 기타를 치려고 해서 어제부터 매일 연습하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gital-eul chillyeogo haeseo eoje-buteo maeil yeonseubhago isseoyo.
examples.en: He is trying to play the guitar, so he has been practicing every day since yesterday.

examples.kr: 아들은 학교에 진학하려고 하니까 공부에 집중하려고 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Adeul-eun hakgyoe jinhakhalyeogo hanikkaji, gongbu-e jibjunghalyeogo hago isseoyo.
examples.en: My son is focusing on his studies because he plans to go to college.

title: ~만이 아니다 [mani anida] (Not only)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that the preceding clause is not the only reason or factor; 'not only'.
long_explanation: The '~만이 아니다' pattern is used to express that something is not solely due to one reason, suggesting that additional factors or elements are involved. It is similar to 'not only' in English, highlighting that there is more than one contributing aspect.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 공부하는 것만이 아니라, 일본어와 중국어도 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangug-eoreul gongbuhaneun geos-mani anila, ilbon-eowa junggug-eodo gongbuhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I am not only studying Korean, but also studying Japanese and Chinese.

examples.kr: 그는 배우만이 아니라 각본가이기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun baeumani anila, gagbon-gaigido haeyo.
examples.en: He is not only an actor, but also a scriptwriter.

examples.kr: 이 좋은 결과는 힘든 노력만이 아니라 지속적인 경험이 결합된 결과입니다.
examples.romaji: I jo-eun gyeolgwaneun himdeun nolyeog-mani anila, jisogjeog-in gyeongheom-i gyeolhabdoen gyeolgwaibnida.
examples.en: This good result is due not only to hard work but also to continuous experience.

examples.kr: 우리가 건축에 관심이 있는 것은 미적인 측면만이 아니라 그 기능적인 측면 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Uliga geonchug-e gwan-sim-i issneun geoseun mijeg-in chugmyeon mani anila, geu gineungjeog-in chugmyeon ttaemun-ibnida.
examples.en: Our interest in architecture is not only because of its aesthetic aspects, but also due to its functional aspects.

title: ~마련이다 [maryeonida] (Bound to, tend to)
short_explanation: Used to express that something is bound to happen or that a situation naturally tends to be a certain way.
long_explanation: The expression '마련이다' is used to talk about an inevitability or a fact of life—something that is expected to occur given the nature or circumstances. It often carries a nuance of resignation or acceptance and is similar to the English expressions 'bound to' or 'tend to'.

examples.kr: 사람들이 보는 것을 신경 쓰지 않으려 해도 그럴 수 없는 건 마련이다.
examples.romaji: Saramdeuli boneun geoseul singyeong sseuji aneureo haedo geureol su eobsneun geon maryeonida.
examples.en: Even if you try not to care about what people think, it’s only natural that you can’t help it.

examples.kr: 작은 아이들이 많이 노는 것은, 그 나이의 특성상 당연한 일이 마련이다.
examples.romaji: Jageun aideuli mani noneun geoseun, geu naieui teukseongsang dangyeonhan iri maryeonida.
examples.en: It’s only natural for young children to play a lot given the nature of their age.

examples.kr: 이번에 실패했다고 해서 다음에도 실패할 거라고 확신할 수 없는 건 마련이다.
examples.romaji: Ibeone silpaehaetdago haeseo daeumeodo silpaehal georago hwaksinhal su eobsneun geon maryeonida.
examples.en: Just because you failed this time doesn’t mean you’re bound to fail next time.

examples.kr: 힘든 일이 생기면 우울해지는 건 마련이다.
examples.romaji: Himdeun iri saenggimyeon uulhaejineun geon maryeonida.
examples.en: When hard times hit, it’s natural to feel down.

title: ~면서 [myeonseo] (While)
short_explanation: Used to express two concurrent actions or states; 'while' or 'as'.
long_explanation: '~면서' is a grammatical structure used to indicate that two actions or states occur simultaneously. It carries the same meaning as 'while' or 'as' in English and is used when the same subject is performing both actions.

examples.kr: 저는 음악을 듣으면서 공부하는 게 좋아해요, 그렇게 하면 더 집중할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eumageul deudneunmyeonseo gongbureul haneun ge joaheoyo, geureokehamyeon deo jipjunghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I like studying while listening to music because I can focus better that way.

examples.kr: 그는 밥을 먹으면서 텔레비전을 봐요, 그것은 그의 습관이에요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun babeul meogneunmyeonseo tellebijeoneul bwayo, geugeoseun geuui seupgwani eyo.
examples.en: He watches television while eating; that is his habit.

examples.kr: 영화를 보면서 점심을 먹었어요, 그럼 시간을 절약할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwaleul bomyeonseo jeomsimeul meogeosseoyo, geureom siganeul jeolyaghall su isseoyo.
examples.en: I ate lunch while watching a movie, so I was able to save time.

examples.kr: 나는 운동하면서 팟캐스트를 들어요, 그건 나에게 유익해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun undonghamyeonseo patkaeseuteureul deureoyo, geugeun naege yuikehaeyo.
examples.en: I listen to podcasts while exercising; it is beneficial to me.

title: ~동안 [dongan] (During/While)
short_explanation: Used to express the duration of an action or situation.
long_explanation: '~동안' indicates the time span during which an action or situation occurs. It typically translates to 'during' or 'while' in English and is useful for describing ongoing actions over a period of time.

examples.kr: 저는 겨울 방학 동안 그림을 많이 그렸어요, 왜냐하면 그것이 제 취미이기 때문이죠.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gyeoul banghak dongan geurimeul manhi geuryeosseoyo, waenyahamyeon geugeosi je chwimigie ttaemunijyo.
examples.en: I drew a lot during winter break because it’s my hobby.

examples.kr: 요리하는 동안 전화가 계속 울려서 요리에 집중할 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Yorihaneun dongan jeonhwaga gyesok ullyeoseo yorie jibjunghal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: While I was cooking, the phone kept ringing so I couldn’t concentrate on it.

examples.kr: 저는 노래방에서 노래 부르는 동안 친구들은 모두 춤을 췄어서 너무 재미있었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun noraebangeseo norae buneun dongan chingudeureun modu chumeul chwoseo neomu jaemiisseosseoyo.
examples.en: While I was singing at the karaoke, all my friends were dancing and it was so much fun.

examples.kr: 그녀는 집에 없는 동안 도둑이 와서 그녀의 모든 가치 있는 것들을 훔쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jibe eopseun dongan doduki waseo geunyeoui modeun gachi inneun geosdeureul humchyeosseoyo.
examples.en: While she was away from home, a thief came and stole all her valuable things.

title: ~부터는 [buteoneun] (From now on, since)
short_explanation: Used to express a change starting from a specific point in time; 'from now on', 'since', or 'after'.
long_explanation: '~부터는' is a time-based postposition that marks the point from which a change occurs or a new condition starts. It can refer to events in the past, present, or future and signals that things will continue or change from that point onward.

examples.kr: 오늘부터는 건강에 좀 더 신경 쓰기로 했어요. 그래서, 매일 아침에 조깅하려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Oneulbuteoneun geongang-e jom deo singyeong sseugiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo, maeil achime jogingharyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: From today, I decided to pay more attention to my health. So, I plan to jog every morning.

examples.kr: 이 사건이 발생한 후부터는 모든 것이 변했습니다. 사람들은 이 사실을 알게 된 후 조금 더 조심스럽게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: I sageoni balghan hubuteoneun modeun geosi byeonhaetsseumnida. Saramdeureun i sasileul alge doen hu jogeum deo josimseureopge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Everything changed after this incident occurred. People became a bit more cautious once they learned about it.

examples.kr: 작년부터는 우리가 번 돈을 좀 더 아껴 쓰기로 했어요. 그래서, 쓸데없는 비용을 아끼기 위해 최대한 노력하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jagnyeonbuteoneun uriga beon doneul jom deo akkyeo sseugiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo, sseuldeeopsneun biyongeul akkigi wihae choedaejeon noryeokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: Since last year, we decided to save more of our earnings. So, we are doing our utmost to cut unnecessary expenses.

examples.kr: 이 보고서를 읽은 후부터는 이 상황에 대해 더 잘 이해할 수 있었어요. 이상하게도, 전에는 이해할 수 없었던 부분들이 갑자기 말이 되더군요.
examples.romaji: I bogoseoreul ilgeun hubuteoneun i sanghwange daehae deo jal ihaehal su isseosseoyo. Isanghagedo, jeoneneun ihaehal su eopseotdeon bundeuli gapjagi mari doedeogunyo.
examples.en: Since reading this report, I was able to understand the situation better. Strangely, the parts I couldn’t grasp before suddenly made sense.

title: ~서야 [seoya] (Only after)
short_explanation: Used to express that only after doing A can B be done, emphasizing the sequential order of events.
long_explanation: '~서야' is used to indicate that the second action or condition can occur only after the first has been completed. It stresses that without fulfilling the prerequisite, the following action is impossible—much like saying 'only after' in English.

examples.kr: 제 책을 모두 읽어서야 이해할 수 있을 것입니다. 가볍게 넘기는 것이 아니라 매 문장, 매 단어를 세심하게 살펴봐야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Je chaeg-eul modu ilgeoseoya ihaehal su iss-eul geos-ibnida. Gabyeobge neomgineun geos-i anila mae munjang, mae dan-eoreul sesimhage salpyeobwaya hamnida.
examples.en: You can only understand my book after reading it all; you must carefully examine every sentence and every word, not just skim through it.

examples.kr: 사랑에 빠져서야 그 사람의 장단점을 보게 되는 거예요. 때로는 사랑의 맹목성 때문에 그들의 단점을 무시하게 될 수도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sarang-e ppajyeoseoya geu saram-ui jangdanjeomeul boge doeneun geoeyo. Ttaeloneun sarang-ui maengmogseong ttaemune geudeul-ui danjeomeul mushihage doel su-do iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Only after falling in love can you see that person’s strengths and weaknesses. Sometimes, the blindness of love may cause you to overlook their flaws.

examples.kr: 이 비즈니스를 성공하려면 계획을 잘 세워서야 할 수 있습니다. 계획 없이 성공을 기대하는 것은 무리가 크다고 생각합니다.
examples.romaji: I bijeuniseuleul seonggonghalyeomyeon gyeheog-eul jal sewoseoya hal su issseubnida. Gyeheog eobs-i seonggong-eul gidaehaneun geoseun muliga keudago saeng-gaghabnida.
examples.en: To succeed in this business, you must plan well first. Expecting success without a plan is unrealistic.

examples.kr: 아무도 겪어보지 않은 상황이라서 고민이긴 하지만, 그 상황을 직접 겪어서야 정확한 대처 방법을 알 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Amudo gyeogeoboji anh-eun sanghwang-ilaseo gomin-igin hajiman, geu sanghwang-eul jigjeob gyeogeoseoya jeonghwaghan daecheo bangbeob-eul al su iss-eul geos-ibnida.
examples.en: It’s a situation no one has ever experienced, so it’s worrisome—but you’ll know the exact way to handle it only after you’ve gone through it yourself.

title: ~소문에는 [somuneneun] (I heard that)
short_explanation: Used to convey a hearsay or rumor that the speaker has heard.
long_explanation: The '~소문에는' construction is used when the speaker wants to indicate that something has been heard as a rumor or hearsay. It does not express the speaker’s own opinion but relays what is commonly talked about.

examples.kr: 소문에는 그 회사가 곧 파산하게 될 것이라고 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Somuneneun geu hoesaga got pasanhage doel geosirago deureosseoyo.
examples.en: I heard that that company is going to go bankrupt soon.

examples.kr: 그의 성공에 대한 소문에는 그가 하루에 18시간 일한다고 해요.
examples.romaji: Geuui seonggonge daehan somuneneun geuga harue 18sigan ilhandago haeyo.
examples.en: The rumor about his success is that he works 18 hours a day.

examples.kr: 그녀가 유명해진 소문에는 그녀가 내년에 할리우드 영화에 출연할 것이라고 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga yumyeonghaejin somuneneun geunyeoga naenyeone hallyuudeu yeonghaee chulyeonhal geosirago haeyo.
examples.en: The rumor about her rising fame is that she will appear in a Hollywood movie next year.

examples.kr: 요즘 임재범의 인기에 대한 소문에는 그가 새로운 앨범을 더 빠르게 발표할 예정이라고 해요.
examples.romaji: Yojum limjaebeomui ingie daehan somuneneun geuga saeroun aelbeumeul deo ppareuge balpyohal yejeongirago haeyo.
examples.en: The rumor about Lim Jae-beom’s current popularity is that he is planning to release a new album sooner.

title: ~아/어 보이다 [a/eo boida] (To seem, appear)
short_explanation: Used to express that someone or something seems or appears a certain way, based on the speaker’s perception.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~아/어 보이다' is used in Korean to convey the speaker’s judgment or perception about someone or something. The verb or adjective before '~아/어 보이다' is conjugated according to its final vowel, and the expression is equivalent to 'seem', 'appear', or 'look like' in English.

examples.kr: 그 남자가 정말 불쌍해 보여요, 아마 어려운 시기를 겪고 있는 것 같네요.
examples.romaji: Geu namjaga jeongmal bulssanghae boyeoyo, ama eoryeoun sigireul geotgo issneun geot gatneyo.
examples.en: That man seems very pitiful; he must be going through a hard time.

examples.kr: 오늘 피곤해 보이니까 일찍 쉬는 게 어때요?
examples.romaji: Oneul pigonhae boinikka, iljjik swineun ge eottaeyo?
examples.en: You look tired today—how about getting some rest early?

examples.kr: 그녀는 행복해 보이는데, 아마 좋은 일이 있었나 봐요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun haengbokhae boineunde, ama joheun iri isseotna bwayo.
examples.en: She seems happy; maybe something good has happened to her.

examples.kr: 이 요리가 맛있어 보이니까 내일 친구들과 함께 와서 먹어 볼게요.
examples.romaji: I yoriga masisseo boinikkaji, naeil chingudeulgwa hamkke wasseo meogeobolkkeyo.
examples.en: This dish looks delicious; I’ll come and try it with my friends tomorrow.

title: ~아/어야지 [a/eoyaji] (I should, I better)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's determination or intention; 'I should' or 'I better'.
long_explanation: ‘~아/어야지’ is a Korean grammar point used to express the speaker’s determination or intention. It conveys that the speaker feels they should do something or had better do it. It is often used when making a self-suggestion or deciding to take a certain action in the future, and sometimes used rhetorically to encourage oneself.
formation: Verb stem + 아/어야지 (if the stem ends in ㅏ or ㅗ, use 아야지; otherwise, use 어야지)

examples.kr: 너무 늦었어, 이제 집에 가야지.
examples.romaji: Neomu neujeosseo, ije jibe gayaji.
examples.en: It's too late, I should go home now.

examples.kr: 이번에는 정말로 다이어트를 해야지.
examples.romaji: Ibeoneneun jeongmallo daieoteureul haeyaji.
examples.en: This time, I really should go on a diet.

examples.kr: 내일은 일찍 일어나서 운동해야지.
examples.romaji: Naeireun iljjik ireonaseo undonghaeyaji.
examples.en: I should wake up early and exercise tomorrow.

examples.kr: 과제가 많이 쌓였어, 이제부터 열심히 해야지.
examples.romaji: Gwajega manhi ssahyeosseo, ijebuteo yeolsimhi haeyaji.
examples.en: I’ve piled up lots of assignments; I should really start working hard from now on.

title: ~았/었다 치다 [at/eotda chida] (Let’s say, suppose)
short_explanation: Expresses a hypothetical situation, equivalent to 'let's say' or 'suppose'.
long_explanation: ‘~았/었다 치다’ is used to propose a hypothetical situation or condition. It is equivalent to saying 'let’s say' or 'suppose' in English, setting up an assumed scenario for discussion. This expression is often used to analyze possible outcomes or to plan by exploring various scenarios.

examples.kr: 우리가 돈이 많았다 치면, 유럽 여행을 갈 수 있었을까요?
examples.romaji: Uriga doni manhatda chimyeon, yureop yeohaengeul gal su isseosseulkka yo?
examples.en: Let's say we had a lot of money; would we have been able to go to Europe?

examples.kr: 그가 우리 팀에 있었다 치면, 이길 수 있었다고 생각해요?
examples.romaji: Geuga uri time isseotda chimyeon, igil su isseotdago saenggakhaeyo?
examples.en: If we suppose that he was on our team, do you think we could have won?

examples.kr: 그녀가 없었다 치면, 그 일을 어떻게 대처했을까요?
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga eopseotda chimyeon, geu ireul eotteoke daecheohaesseulkka yo?
examples.en: Let's say she wasn't there; how would we have dealt with that?

examples.kr: 요즘 비가 많이 왔다 치면, 야외 활동은 어떻게 될까요?
examples.romaji: Yojeum biga mani watda chimyeon, yaoe hwaldongeun eotteoke doilgeolkka yo?
examples.en: Suppose it has rained a lot these days; how would outdoor activities be affected?

title: ~았/었던 것 같다 [at/eotdeon geot gatda] (It seemed that)
short_explanation: Used to express that something appeared or seemed a certain way in the past.
long_explanation: ‘~았/었던 것 같다’ is used to express a speaker’s vague recollection or speculation about a past event. It can be translated as 'it seemed that', 'it looked as if', or 'I think that', often indicating uncertainty or a vague impression.
formation: Verb in past tense + ~았/었던 것 같다

examples.kr: 그녀는 매우 행복했던 것 같아요, 항상 미소를 짓고 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun maeu haengbokhaetdeon geot gatayo, hangsang misoreul jitgo isseosseoyo.
examples.en: She seemed very happy; she was always smiling.

examples.kr: 그 날은 들어보지 못했던 노래를 들었던 것 같아요, 그 노래는 아직도 머릿속에 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geu nareun deureoboji moshan nolaereul deureossdeon geot gatayo, geu nolaeneun ajikdo meoritsoge isseoyo.
examples.en: I think that on that day I heard a song I had never heard before; that song is still in my head.

examples.kr: 저는 아주 오래전에 이곳을 방문했던 것 같아요, 건물들이 익숙해 보여요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun aju oraejeon-e igoseul bangmunhaetdeon geot gatayo, geonmuldeuri iksukhae boyeoyo.
examples.en: I think I visited this place a very long time ago; the buildings look familiar.

examples.kr: 오늘이 일요일인 줄 알았던 것 같아요, 하지만 사실은 토요일이었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneuli iryoil-in jul aratdeon geot gatayo, hajiman sasil-eun toyoilieosseoyo.
examples.en: I think I mistakenly thought today was Sunday, but it was actually Saturday.

title: ~았/었어야 했다 [at/eosseoya haetda] (Should have)
short_explanation: Expresses regret over something in the past that should have been done but wasn't.
long_explanation: ‘~았/었어야 했다’ is used to express regret or a sense of missed opportunity about a past action. It is equivalent to 'should have' in English and reflects on an action that did not occur but would have been appropriate or beneficial if it had.

examples.kr: 이제 와서 미안하다고 하는 것은 늦었어, 처음에 아무래도 잘못을 인정했어야 했어.
examples.romaji: Ije waseo mianhadago haneun geoseun neujeosseo, cheoeume amuraedo jalmoseul injeonghaesseoya haesseo.
examples.en: It's too late to apologize now; you should have admitted your mistake from the beginning.

examples.kr: 그 이야기를 듣기 전에, 날 믿었어야 했어.
examples.romaji: Geu iyagireul deutgi jeone, nal mideosseoya haesseo.
examples.en: You should have believed me before hearing that story.

examples.kr: 나는 그 회사에 지원하지 말았어야 했어, 거기서의 경험은 나에게 좋지 않았어.
examples.romaji: Naneun geu hoesae jiweonhaji marasseoya haesseo, geogiseoui gyeongheomeun naege joji anhasseo.
examples.en: I shouldn't have applied to that company; the experience there wasn't good for me.

examples.kr: 우리는 더 일찍 출발했어야 했어, 그래서 지금보다 더 많은 관광지를 볼 수 있었을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Urineun deo iljjik chulbalhaesseoya haesseo, geuraeseo jigeumboda deo manheun gwangwangjireul bol su isseosseultende.
examples.en: We should have left earlier, so we could have seen more tourist attractions.

title: ~어/아 가다 [eo/a gada] (While doing)
short_explanation: Describes an action that is ongoing or a process that continues over time.
long_explanation: ‘~어/아 가다’ is used to indicate that an action started in the past is continuing into the present or future. It can be translated as 'while doing' or 'gradually' and is used to emphasize a process or change over time.

examples.kr: 저는 음악을 들으면서 걸어갈 거예요, 그래서 스트레스를 줄일 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eumageul deureumyeonseo georeogal geoyeyo, geuraeseo seuteureseureul julil su isseoyo.
examples.en: I will go while listening to music, so I can reduce stress.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 매일 아침 운동하면서 가던 공원에 가곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun maeil achim undonghamyeonseo gadeon gongwone gagon haeyo.
examples.en: My mother often goes to the park she used to go to while exercising every morning.

examples.kr: 아기가 성장하면서 점점 더 많은 것을 배워가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Agiga seongjanghamyeonseo jeomjeom deo manheun geoseul baewogago isseoyo.
examples.en: As the baby grows, it is learning more and more.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어를 공부하면서 점차 나아져가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeoreul gongbuhamyeonseo jeomjeom naajyeogago isseoyo.
examples.en: I am gradually improving while studying Korean.

title: ~어/아 달라다 [eo/a dallada] (To ask to do)
short_explanation: Used to request someone to do something, often in a formal or polite manner.
long_explanation: ‘~어/아 달라다’ is used to express a request for someone to perform an action. This form is typically employed in indirect or reported requests – usually followed by the quotation marker ‘-라고’ – and is most appropriate in formal or respectful contexts.
formation: Verb stem + 어/아 달라다 (with appropriate vowel harmony; in reported speech, it becomes 달라고)

examples.kr: 선생님, 이 말로 다시 한 번 설명해 달라고 부탁드립니다.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnim, i mallo dasi han beon seolmyeonghae dallago butakdeurimnida.
examples.en: Teacher, I kindly ask you to explain this word once more.

examples.kr: 제가 이해하지 못했기 때문에, 다시 한 번 설명해 달라고 요청했습니다.
examples.romaji: Jega ihaehaji mothaetgi ttaemune, dasi han beon seolmyeonghae dallago yocheonghaetseumnida.
examples.en: Because I didn't understand, I requested that it be explained once more.

examples.kr: 친구에게 그리는 방법을 가르쳐 달라고 부탁했습니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguege geurineun bangbeobeul gareuchyeo dallago butakhaetseumnida.
examples.en: I asked my friend to teach me how to draw.

examples.kr: 의사에게 증상에 대해 자세히 설명해 달라고 부탁했습니다.
examples.romaji: Uisaege jeungsange daehae jasehi seolmyeonghae dallago butakhaetseumnida.
examples.en: I asked the doctor to explain the symptoms in detail.

title: ~어/아 다니다 [eo/a danida] (To attend, to go regularly)
short_explanation: Used to indicate habitual or regular attendance/visiting of a place.
long_explanation: ‘~어/아 다니다’ is used to express that someone regularly attends or visits a place, such as a school, workplace, or other location. It conveys the idea of a habitual or routine action.
formation: Typically used with place-related verbs (e.g., 학교에 다니다, 도서관에 다니다)

examples.kr: 저는 매일 학교에 다녀요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil hakgyoe danyeoyo.
examples.en: I go to school every day.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자주 도서관에 다녀요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jaju doseogwane danyeoyo.
examples.en: She often goes to the library.

examples.kr: 우리는 주말마다 시장에 다녀요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jumalmada sijange danyeoyo.
examples.en: We go to the market every weekend.

examples.kr: 동생은 방과 후에 학원에 다녀요.
examples.romaji: Dongsaengeun banggwa hue hagwone danyeoyo.
examples.en: My younger sibling attends academy after school.

title: ~어/아 두다 [eo/a duda] (To leave something as is, to do in advance)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that an action is performed and its resulting state is maintained or preserved for future reference.
long_explanation: ‘~어/아 두다’ is used to express that an action has been performed so that its result remains unchanged. It often implies preparing something in advance or leaving something in a particular state for later use.

examples.kr: 문을 열어 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Muneul yeoreo dueosseoyo.
examples.en: I left the door open.

examples.kr: 내일 쓸 음식을 미리 준비해 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil sseul eumsigeul miri junbihae dueosseoyo.
examples.en: I prepared the food for tomorrow in advance.

examples.kr: 그는 숙제를 다 해 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun sukjereul da hae dueosseoyo.
examples.en: He finished his homework and left it done.

examples.kr: 가게 문을 닫아 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Gage muneul dada dueosseoyo.
examples.en: I kept the store door closed.

title: ~어/아 들다 [eo/a deulda] (Suddenly start to)
short_explanation: Used mainly in narrative contexts to indicate a sudden or unexpected onset of an action or state.
long_explanation: ‘~어/아 들다’ is a grammatical structure used in Korean storytelling to express that an action or emotion began abruptly or unintentionally. Often marked by a contrasting clause with ‘들더니’, it conveys a sudden change. Note that this form is less common in everyday conversation than '~기 시작하다'.
formation: Verb stem + 어/아 들다 (use 아 if the stem ends in ㅏ or ㅗ; otherwise, use 어)

examples.kr: 그 말을 듣자, 동생이 웃어 들더니 이내 진지해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Geu mareul deutja, dongsaengi useo deuldeoni inaejinjahaejyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Upon hearing those words, my younger sibling suddenly burst into laughter, then quickly became serious.

examples.kr: 아이가 울어 들더니 곧 웃음을 터뜨렸어요.
examples.romaji: Aiga ul-eo deuldeoni god useumeul teotteuryeosseoyo.
examples.en: The child suddenly started crying, then burst out laughing shortly after.

examples.kr: 바람이 세차게 불어 들더니 창문이 쾅 닫혔어요.
examples.romaji: Barami sechage buleo deuldeoni changmuni kkwang dathyeosseoyo.
examples.en: When the wind blew fiercely, the window suddenly slammed shut.

examples.kr: 해가 지자, 하늘이 어둡어 들더니 별들이 나타났어요.
examples.romaji: Haega jija, haneuli eodubeo deuldeoni byeoldeuri natanasseoyo.
examples.en: When the sun set, the sky suddenly darkened, and stars appeared.

title: ~어/아 버리다 [eo/a beorida] (To end up doing, regrettably)
short_explanation: Expresses an action that was completed—often unexpectedly or with regret.
long_explanation: ‘~어/아 버리다’ is used in Korean to indicate that an action has been carried out completely, sometimes conveying a sense of regret, loss, or unintended finality. It emphasizes that something happened in its entirety, often in a way that the speaker wishes it hadn’t.

examples.kr: 커피를 다 마셔버렸어요, 그래서 이제 더 이상 마실 수가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Keopireul da masyeobeoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo ije deo isang masil suga eopseoyo.
examples.en: I ended up drinking all the coffee, so now I can't drink any more.

examples.kr: 고양이가 내 신발을 뜯어버렸어, 그래서 이제 새로운 신발을 사야 해.
examples.romaji: Goyangiga nae sinbaleul tteobeoryeosseo, geuraeseo ije saeroun sinbaleul saya hae.
examples.en: The cat ended up tearing my shoes, so now I need to buy new ones.

examples.kr: 다이어트를 하려고 했는데, 케이크를 다 먹어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Daieoteureul haryeogo haeneunde, keikeureul da meogeobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was trying to diet, but I ended up eating the whole cake.

examples.kr: 결국, 공부하지 않고 시험 전날 밤동안 교과서를 다 읽어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Gyeolguk, gongbuhaji anhgo siheom jeon nal bamdongan gyogwaseoreul da ilgeobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: In the end, I didn’t study and ended up reading the entire textbook the night before the exam.

title: ~어/아 보다 [eo/a boda] (To try doing)
short_explanation: Used when the speaker expresses the intention of trying to do something.
long_explanation: '~어/아 보다' is used to indicate an attempt or trial of an action. The verb preceding '보다' shows what is being attempted, while the overall tense of the sentence is determined by the form of '보다'. It hints at testing an action to see what happens.

examples.kr: 오늘은 처음으로 한국어를 가르쳐 볼까 생각하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun cheoeumeuro hangugeoreul gareuchyeo bolkka saenggakago isseoyo.
examples.en: I am thinking of trying to teach Korean for the first time today.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에 당신이 추천한 카페에서 커피를 마셔 볼 예정입니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumare dangsin-i chuchheonhan kapeeseo keopireul masyeo bol yejeongimnida.
examples.en: I plan to try the coffee at the cafe you recommended this weekend.

examples.kr: 그녀는 새로운 요리법을 찾아서 요리를 해 보려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun saeroun yoribeobeul chajaseo yorireul hae boryeogo hamnida.
examples.en: She is going to try cooking by finding a new recipe.

examples.kr: 내일은 그 도시를 처음 방문해서 주변을 둘러 보려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naeireun geu dosireul cheoeum bangmunhaeseo jubyeoneul dolreo boryeogo hamnida.
examples.en: Tomorrow, I will try to look around by visiting that city for the first time.

title: ~고 나서 [go naseo] (After doing)
short_explanation: Indicates that after one action is completed, another action follows naturally.
long_explanation: The expression '~고 나서' is used to show a sequence of events—once action A is completed, action B takes place. It conveys that the completion of the first action sets the stage for what comes next.

examples.kr: 집에 가서 밥을 먹고 나서 공부해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jibe gaseo bapeul meokgo naseo gongbuhaya haeyo.
examples.en: I have to go home, eat, and then study.

examples.kr: 요가 수업에 참석하고 나서 몸이 더 유연해질 것이에요.
examples.romaji: Yoga sueobe chamseokhago naseo momi deo yuyeonhaejil geosieyo.
examples.en: After attending a yoga class, my body will become more flexible.

examples.kr: 시험을 마치고 나서 휴식을 취하려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul machigo naseo hyusigeul chwiharyeogo hamnida.
examples.en: I plan to take a rest after finishing the exam.

examples.kr: 운동하고 나서 단백질 섭취를 늘릴 필요가 있어요.
examples.romaji: Undonghago naseo danbaekjil seobchwireul neulril pillyoga isseoyo.
examples.en: I need to increase my protein intake after exercising.

title: ~어/아 오다 [eo/a oda] (To come to do)
short_explanation: Expresses a gradual change or process that has accumulated over time.
long_explanation: ‘~어/아 오다’ is used to indicate that a change or development has been coming about gradually. It is often attached to an action verb to show that, over time, a new state has been reached—frequently with a nuance of unexpectedness.

examples.kr: 영화를 계속 보면서 점점 스토리에 흥미를 느껴 오게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwaleul gyesok bomyeonseo jeomjeom seutorie heungmireul neukkyeo oge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: As I kept watching the movie, I gradually came to be interested in the story.

examples.kr: 연습을 반복하면서 저는 점점 한국어를 더 잘하게 되어 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonseubeul banbokhamyeonseo jeoneun jeomjeom hangugeoreul deo jalhage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: As I repeated my practice, I gradually became better at Korean.

examples.kr: 시간이 지나면서 그녀는 점점 나를 더 이해하게 되어 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Sigani jinamyeonseo geunyeoneun jeomjeom nareul deo ihaehage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Over time, she gradually came to understand me better.

examples.kr: 알게 되면서 점점 우리 사이가 더 가까워져 오고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Alge doemyeonseo jeomjeom uri saiga deo gakkawojyeo ogo isseoyo.
examples.en: As we got to know each other, our relationship has gradually become closer.

title: ~어/아지다 [eo/ajida] (Become)
short_explanation: Used to express change or transformation; essentially, 'become'.
long_explanation: ‘~어/아지다’ is attached to descriptive verbs (adjectives) to indicate that something has changed or transformed into a new state. The form ‘~어지다’ is used if the stem ends in a vowel, and ‘~아지다’ is used if it ends in a consonant.

examples.kr: 날이 점점 더워져서 집에서만 쉬기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Nali jeomjeom deoweojyeoseo jibeseoman swigiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: As it got increasingly hot, I decided to stay home and rest.

examples.kr: 제 친구가 너무 바빠져서 우리는 자주 만나지 못하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguga neomu bappajyeoseo urineun jaju mannaji mothage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: My friend became so busy that we couldn’t meet often.

examples.kr: 이 공원은 계절이 바뀔 때마다 아름다워져서 많은 사람들이 찾아와요.
examples.romaji: I gongwaneun gyejeoli bakkul ttaemada areumdaweojyeoseo manheun saramdeuri chajawayo.
examples.en: This park becomes more beautiful with each changing season, attracting many visitors.

examples.kr: 방이 난로를 틀어서 따뜻해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Bangi nanloureul teureoseo ttatteuthaejyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The room became warm when the heater was turned on.

title: ~었으면 좋겠다 [eosseumyeon jotgetda] (I wish it was/were)
short_explanation: Expresses a wish or desire for something that did not happen or is unreal.
long_explanation: ‘~었으면 좋겠다’ is used to express a wish or regret regarding an unfulfilled or unreal situation. It can convey a longing for a different outcome—whether about the past, present, or future.

examples.kr: 그때 그녀에게 내 진심을 말했으면 좋겠다.
examples.romaji: Geuttae geunyeoege nae jinsimeul malhaesseumyeon jotgetda.
examples.en: I wish I had told her my true feelings at that time.

examples.kr: 집에 더 일찍 돌아갔으면 좋겠다.
examples.romaji: Jibe deo iljjik doragasseumyeon jotgetda.
examples.en: I wish I had come home earlier.

examples.kr: 당신이 저를 더 이해했으면 좋겠다.
examples.romaji: Dangsini jeoreul deo ihaehaesseumyeon jotgetda.
examples.en: I wish you had understood me better.

examples.kr: 내가 그 사실을 알았으면 좋겠다.
examples.romaji: Naega geu sasileul alasseumyeon jotgetda.
examples.en: I wish I had known that fact.

title: ~에 한하다 [e hanhada] (Limited to)
short_explanation: Indicates that something is applicable only under a certain condition or case.
long_explanation: The pattern ‘~에 한하다’ is used to express that a rule, offer, or situation applies exclusively to a specific case or condition. In English it is often translated as 'limited to' or 'applicable only to'.

examples.kr: 이번 할인행사는 오늘에 한해 적용됩니다. 다른 날에는 적용되지 않습니다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon halinhaengsaneun oneule hanhae jeogyongdoemnida. Dareun nareun jeogyongdoeji anhseumnida.
examples.en: This discount event applies only today; it does not apply on any other day.

examples.kr: 저의 사랑은 그녀에 한하며, 다른 사람에게는 전혀 관심이 없습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoui sarangeun geunyeo-e hanhamyeo, dareun saramege-neun jeonhyeo gwansimi eopseumnida.
examples.en: My love is limited solely to her; I have no interest in anyone else.

examples.kr: 이 제품의 보증서 서비스는 원래 구매자에 한해 제공됩니다.
examples.romaji: I jepumui bojeungseo seobiseuneun wonrae gumaeja-e hanhae jegongdoemnida.
examples.en: The warranty service for this product is provided only to the original purchaser.

examples.kr: 이번 행사는 회원에 한해 참여 가능합니다. 비회원은 참여할 수 없습니다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon haengsaneun hoewon-e hanhae chamyeo ganeunghamnida. Bihoewoneun chamyeohal su eopseumnida.
examples.en: This event is limited to members; non-members cannot participate.

title: ~에 한해서 [e hanhaeseo] (Only in, limited to)
short_explanation: Specifies that something is valid or available only under a particular condition or circumstance.
long_explanation: ‘~에 한해서’ is used to indicate that a rule, offer, or situation applies exclusively when a specific condition is met. It means 'only in' or 'limited to' the stated context, implying that it does not extend to other cases.

examples.kr: 내일 휴일이기에 한해서 오늘 밤 늦게까지 일할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil hyuiligi-e hanhaeseo oneul bam neutgekkaji ilhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Because tomorrow is a holiday, I can work until late tonight.

examples.kr: 이 특별 할인은 VIP 고객에 한해서 제공되는 서비스입니다.
examples.romaji: I teukbyeol halineun VIP gogaeg-e hanhaeseo jegongdoeneun seobiseuimnida.
examples.en: This special discount is a service provided only for VIP customers.

examples.kr: 우리는 오늘에 한해서 무제한 음료를 제공합니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun oneule hanhaeseo mujehan eumryoreul jegonghamnida.
examples.en: We provide unlimited drinks only for today.

examples.kr: 이 모바일 쿠폰은 스타벅스 매장에 한해서 사용 가능합니다.
examples.romaji: I mobail coupon-eun Starbucks maejang-e hanhaeseo sayong ganeunghamnida.
examples.en: This mobile coupon can be used only at Starbucks stores.

title: ~에 힘쓰다 [e himsseuda] (Put effort into)
short_explanation: Describes the act of putting a lot of effort into or striving for something.
long_explanation: ‘~에 힘쓰다’ is used to indicate that someone is dedicating significant effort toward achieving a goal or maintaining a state. It can be translated as 'to put effort into', 'to strive for', or 'to work hard for' a particular objective.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어 학습에 힘쓰고 있어요, 아직 부족하지만 나아질 것이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeo hakseube himsseugo isseoyo, ajik bujog hajiman naajil geosieyo.
examples.en: I'm putting effort into learning Korean; it’s still not perfect, but it will improve.

examples.kr: 그녀는 공부에 힘쓰기 시작했고, 결과는 항상 좋았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gongbu-e himsseugi sijakhaessgo, gyeolgwaneun hangsang joasseoyo.
examples.en: She began to put effort into studying, and the results were always good.

examples.kr: 우리 팀은 이 프로젝트에 최선을 다하려고 힘쓰고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri tim-eun i peurojekteue choiseoneul daharyeogo himsseugo isseoyo.
examples.en: Our team is striving to do our best in this project.

examples.kr: 친구들이 몸건강 챙기기에 힘쓰는 것을 보니 매우 자랑스러워요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeul-i momgeongang chaengigie himsseuneun geoseul boni maeu jarangseureowayo.
examples.en: Seeing my friends put effort into taking care of their health makes me very proud.

title: ~으나마나 [eunamana] (It's no use, to no avail)
short_explanation: Used to convey that an effort or expectation was in vain.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~으나마나' is used in Korean to express that an action or effort yielded no meaningful or positive result. It implies that no matter how much one does, the outcome remains unsatisfactory. This structure is generally used in negative contexts.

examples.kr: 나는 시험을 잘 볼려고 열심히 공부했으나마나, 결과는 항상 만족스럽지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun siheomeul jal bollyeogo yeolsimhi gongbuhaesseumana, gyeolgwa-neun hangsang manjokseureopji anasseoyo.
examples.en: No matter how hard I studied to do well on the exam, the result was always unsatisfactory.

examples.kr: 우리는 빨리 도착하기 위해 택시를 탔으나마나, 결국 지각했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun ppalli dochak hagi wihae taeksireul tasseumana, gyeolguk jigakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Even though we took a taxi to arrive quickly, we ended up being late.

examples.kr: 그는 병원에 가서 약을 가져왔으나마나, 증상이 전혀 나아지지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun byeongwone gaseo yag-eul gajyeowasseumana, jeungsing-i jeonhyeo naajiji anasseoyo.
examples.en: Despite going to the hospital and getting medicine, the symptoms did not improve at all.

examples.kr: 난 그녀에게 사과했으나마나, 그녀는 나를 용서하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Nan geunyeoege sagwahaesseumana, geunyeoneun naleul yongseohaji anasseoyo.
examples.en: Although I apologized to her, she did not forgive me.

title: ~으니/니까 [euni/nikka] (So, since, because)
short_explanation: Expresses a reason or cause; similar to 'so', 'since', or 'because'.
long_explanation: '~으니/니까' is a conjunction used to denote a cause-and-effect relationship between two clauses. It provides a reason or explanation for the following statement and is widely used to justify why something happens.

examples.kr: 오늘은 토요일이니까 학교에 가지 않아요, 주말에는 학교를 쉬어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun toyoilinikka hakgyoe gaji anhayo, jumaleneun hakgyoreul swieoyo.
examples.en: Since today is Saturday, I don’t go to school; we have a break on weekends.

examples.kr: 아무도 도와주지 않으니, 스스로 해결해야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Amudo dowajunji aneuni, seuseuro haegyeolhaeya haesseoyo.
examples.en: Since nobody helped me, I had to solve it by myself.

examples.kr: 번역기를 쓰니까, 한국어를 더 쉽게 이해할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Beonyeokgireul sseunikka, hangugeoreul deo swipge ihaehal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since I use a translator, I can understand Korean more easily.

examples.kr: 비가 오니까 우산을 가지고 나가세요, 비를 맞으면 감기에 걸릴 수도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Biga onikka usaneul gajigo nagaseyo, bireul majeumyeon gamgie geollil sudo isseoyo.
examples.en: Since it’s raining, take an umbrella with you; you might catch a cold if you get wet.

title: ~을 바탕으로 [eul batangeuro] (Based on)
short_explanation: Indicates that something is done 'based on' or 'on the basis of' certain information.
long_explanation: '~을 바탕으로' is a postpositional phrase used to express that an action or decision is founded on a particular fact, evidence, or experience. The noun preceding this expression serves as the basis for what follows.

examples.kr: 우리는 고객들의 피드백을 바탕으로 제품을 개선했습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun gogudeul-ui pideubaeg-eul batangeuro jepumeul gaeseonhaetseumnida.
examples.en: We improved the product based on our customers’ feedback.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자신의 경험을 바탕으로 책을 썼습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jasin-ui gyeongheomeul batangeuro chaegeul sseotseumnida.
examples.en: She wrote a book based on her personal experiences.

examples.kr: 저는 이전 회사에서의 경험을 바탕으로 이 작업을 빠르게 마칠 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ijeon hoesaeseoui gyeongheomeul batangeuro i jageobeul bbalge machil su isseumnida.
examples.en: I can complete this task quickly based on my experience at my previous company.

examples.kr: 그들은 사실을 바탕으로 결정을 내렸습니다.
examples.romaji: Geudeureun sasileul batangeuro gyeoljeongeul naeryeotseumnida.
examples.en: They made a decision based on the facts.

title: ~을 빼다 [eul ppaeda] (Except for)
short_explanation: Expresses exclusion; meaning 'except for' or 'aside from'.
long_explanation: '~을 빼다' is used in Korean to exclude a particular item or group from a general statement. It specifies that while a general rule applies, there are exceptions.
formation: Noun + 을/를 빼다 + (rest of the sentence)

examples.kr: 우리 학교에서는 학생들이 모두 친절해요, 몇 명의 학생들을 빼고 모두 친절해요.
examples.romaji: Uri hakgyoeseoneun haksengdeul-i modu chinjeolhaeyo, myeot myeong-ui haksengdeuleul ppaego modu chinjeolhaeyo.
examples.en: In our school, all the students are kind; except for a few, everyone is kind.

examples.kr: 이 식당의 모든 메뉴는 맛있어요, 몇 가지 메뉴를 빼고는 모두 맛있어요.
examples.romaji: I shiktang-ui modeun menyuneun mashisseoyo, myeot gaji menyureul ppaegoneun modu mashisseoyo.
examples.en: All the menus in this restaurant are delicious, except for a few, everything is delicious.

examples.kr: 여기 있는 모든 사람들이 한국어를 할 수 있어요, 몇몇 사람들을 빼고는.
examples.romaji: Yeogi itneun modeun saramdeul-i hangugeoreul hal su isseoyo, myeotmyeot saramdeuleul ppaegoneun.
examples.en: Everyone here can speak Korean, except for a few people.

examples.kr: 읽은 모든 책들 중에서 가장 재미있었어요, 몇 권의 책을 빼고.
examples.romaji: Ilgeun modeun chaegdeul jungeseo gajang jaemiisseotseoyo, myeot gweon-ui chaegeul ppaego.
examples.en: Among all the books I read, it was the most interesting—except for a few.

title: ~을 사이 [eul sai] (Between)
short_explanation: Used to express 'between' or 'among'.
long_explanation: '~을 사이' is used to indicate that something is located between or among two or more items. It is most naturally used with two nouns, often connected with '과/와', to show a spatial or conceptual intermediate position.

examples.kr: 나는 아침 식사와 점심 식사 사이에 간단한 간식을 먹습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun achim siksa-wa jeomsim siksa saie gananhan gansigeul meokseumnida.
examples.en: I have a simple snack between breakfast and lunch.

examples.kr: 첫 번째 작업과 두 번째 작업 사이에 휴식 시간을 갖는 것이 중요합니다.
examples.romaji: Cheot beonjjae jakeob-gwa du beonjjae jakeob saie hyusik siganeul ganeun geosi jungyohamnida.
examples.en: It is important to have a break between the first and second tasks.

examples.kr: 그녀의 집과 학교 사이에 있는 공원에서 공부를 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoui jip-gwa hakgyo saie itneun gongwon-eseo gongbureul haetseumnida.
examples.en: I studied in the park located between her house and the school.

examples.kr: 우리는 두 회사 사이에 있는 레스토랑에서 만났습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun du hoesa saie itneun reseutorang-eseo mannatseumnida.
examples.en: We met at a restaurant situated between the two companies.

title: ~을 테니 [eul teni] (I assume/bet)
short_explanation: Used to express a confident assumption or prediction about a future event.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~을 테니' is used to make a deduction or prediction based on available evidence. It expresses the speaker’s confident guess about a result or outcome, usually followed by a consequent action or result.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올 테니 우산을 가져가는 것이 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga ol teni usaneul gajyeoganeun geosi johgesseoyo.
examples.en: I bet it will rain tomorrow, so it would be wise to bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 진희가 어렸을 때 수영을 배웠을 테니 수영을 잘할 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Jinheega eoryeosseul ttae suyeongeul baewosseul teni suyeongeul jalhal geosimnida.
examples.en: Since Jinhee learned to swim when she was young, she must be good at it.

examples.kr: 그는 일어나서 아침을 먹은 것으로 보입니다. 밥그릇에 밥이 조금 남아 있을 테니 그가 아침을 먹고 간 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun ireonaseo achimeul meogeun geoseuro boimnida. Babgeureute bap-i jogeum nama isseul teni geuga achimeul meokgo gan geosimnida.
examples.en: It appears that he woke up and had breakfast; I assume he left after eating since a little rice remains in the bowl.

examples.kr: 영희가 피곤하다고 해서, 지금은 집에서 잘 테니 전화하지 마세요.
examples.romaji: Yeongheega pigonhadago haeseo, jigeumeun jibeseo jal teni jeonhwahaji maseyo.
examples.en: Since Younghee said she was tired, I bet she’s sleeping at home now. Don’t call her.

title: ~을 통해 [eul tonghae] (Through, via)
short_explanation: Expresses the means or method by which something is done.
long_explanation: The phrase '~을 통해' signifies the channel, method, or process by which an action is carried out. It is used after a noun to show that the following action occurs by way of or through that noun.

examples.kr: 우리는 이메일을 통해 의견을 주고받았어요, 그래서 모두가 표현하기 편했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun imeireul tonghae uigyeoneul jugobadatsseoyo, geuraeseo moduga pyohyeonhagi pyeonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: We exchanged opinions through email, so everyone found it easy to express themselves.

examples.kr: 저는 책을 통해 새로운 지식을 배우는 것을 좋아합니다, 그래서 자주 도서관을 방문합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chaekeul tonghae saeroun jisigeul baeuneun geoseul johahamnida, geuraeseo jaju doseogwaneul bangmunhamnida.
examples.en: I like learning new things through books, so I visit the library frequently.

examples.kr: 그녀는 구글 번역을 통해 한국어를 배우고 있어요, 그래서 언어를 배우는데 편리합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gugle beonyeogeul tonghae hangugeoreul baewugo isseoyo, geuraeseo eoneoreul baewuneunde pyeonrihamnida.
examples.en: She is learning Korean through Google Translate, which makes learning languages convenient for her.

examples.kr: 우리는 마스크 착용을 통해 코로나바이러스의 확산을 막을 수 있었어요, 그래서 많은 생명이 구해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun maseukeu chakyong-eul tonghae koronabaireoseu-ui hwagsan-eul mageul su isseosseoyo, geuraeseo manheun saengmyeong-i guhaejyeosseoyo.
examples.en: We were able to prevent the spread of the coronavirus through wearing masks, thereby saving many lives.

title: ~을/를 틈타 [eul/reul teumta] (Taking advantage of, during)
short_explanation: Describes using a spare moment or opportunity to do something.
long_explanation: '~을/를 틈타' is used to indicate that someone takes advantage of a gap in time or an opportunity to perform an action. It implies doing something in the interim or making use of a favorable situation.

examples.kr: 저는 출근하는 길을 틈타 책을 읽곤 해요, 그래서 지루한 통학 시간을 잘 활용할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chulgeunhaneun gireul teumta chaegeul ilkgon haeyo, geuraeseo jiruhan tonghak siganeul jal hyangyonghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I tend to read books on my way to work, so I can make good use of the long, boring commute.

examples.kr: 그녀는 휴식 시간을 틈타 학습했어요, 그래서 시험 준비가 더 잘 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hyusik siganeul teumta hakseubhaesseoyo, geuraeseo siheom junbiga deo jal doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: She took advantage of her break time to study, so she was better prepared for the exam.

examples.kr: 아기가 잠들 때를 틈타 집안일을 해요, 그래서 많은 일을 처리할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Agiga jamdeul ttaereul teumta jibanireul haeyo, geureoni manheun ildeul-eul cheolihal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I do housework when the baby is asleep, so I can get many tasks done.

examples.kr: 비가 오는 날을 틈타 분위기 있는 카페에서 책을 읽었어요, 정말 평온한 시간이었어요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneun naleul teumta bunwigiga itneun kape-eseo chaegeul ilgyeosseoyo, jeongmallo pyeongonhan siganyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I took advantage of a rainy day to read a book in a cozy cafe; it was a really peaceful time.

title: ~이기는 한데 [igineun hande] (Although, but)
short_explanation: Indicates a contrast by acknowledging one fact while negating or limiting it with another.
long_explanation: '~이기는 한데' is used in Korean to show that while one part of a statement is true, the following part provides a contrasting or limiting remark. It is roughly equivalent to 'although' or 'but' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 그 영화가 재미있게 보기는 한데, 약간의 폭력 씬이 너무 많이 나와서 좀 불편했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun geu yeonghwaga jaemiitge bogineun hande, yakgan-ui pokryeok ssin-i neomu mani nawa seo jom bulpyeonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Although I found that movie entertaining, there were too many violent scenes that made me uncomfortable.

examples.kr: 한국어를 공부하기는 한데, 중국어를 더 잘하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Hangugeoreul gongbu hagi neun hande, junggug-eoreul deo jalhago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: Although I am studying Korean, I want to become better at Chinese.

examples.kr: 우리 팀이 승리하긴 했는데, 상대 팀이 더 잘했어요.
examples.romaji: Uri tim-i seunglihagin haessneunde, sangdaetim-i deo jalhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Although our team won, the opposing team played better.

examples.kr: 내일 체육 대회가 있어서 연습을 많이 해야 하기는 한데, 시간이 없어서 어떻게 할지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil cheyuk daehoega isseoseo yeonseub-eul mani haeya hagin hande, sigani eopseoseo eotteoke halji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: Although I have to practice a lot for tomorrow’s sports festival, I don’t know how to manage it because I have no time.

title: ~이나 [ina] (Or something)
short_explanation: Expresses uncertainty or gives approximate examples, similar to 'or something' or 'or so'.
long_explanation: '~이나' is a particle used in Korean to introduce alternatives or approximate examples when the speaker is not certain of the details or wants to imply that there are other possibilities.

examples.kr: 저는 커피이나 차이나 뭔가 마실게요, 제가 너무 목이 말라서요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopiina chaiina mwonga masilgeyo, jega neomu mogi maraseoyo.
examples.en: I'll have coffee or tea or something, because I'm so thirsty.

examples.kr: 우리는 이번 주말에 피크닉이나 가볼까요? 좋은 날씨를 즐기는 것도 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Urineun ibeon jumal-e piknikina gabolkka? Joeun nalssireul jeulgineun geosdo joheulgeot gatayo.
examples.en: Shall we go for a picnic or something this weekend? It would be nice to enjoy the good weather.

examples.kr: 그녀는 점심으로 라면이나 유부초밥 같은 간단한 것을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jeomsimeuro ramyeonina yubuchobab gateun gandanhan geoseul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: She had something simple like ramen or tofu sushi for lunch.

examples.kr: 나는 10 kilometer이나 걸어가서 집에 돌아왔어요, 왜냐하면 버스가 없었거든요.
examples.romaji: Naneun 10 kilometeoina georeogaseo jibe dorawasseoyo, waenyahamyeon beoseuga eopseosseoya.
examples.en: I walked about 10 kilometers or so to get home because there was no bus.

title: ~이래 [irae] (Since then, like this)
short_explanation: Expresses that a state or action has continued from a past point until now, or describes the manner in which something is done.
long_explanation: '~이래' is used in Korean to indicate that a situation has continued from a specific point in the past to the present, or to describe how something is done. It is generally translated as 'since then' or 'like this' in English.

examples.kr: 학교에서 그녀를 처음 만난 이래로 그녀를 사랑하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoeseo geunyeoreul cheoeum mannan iraero, geunyeoreul saranghage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Since I first met her in school, I have fallen in love with her.

examples.kr: 인디아에 와서는 처음으로 매운 음식을 먹어 본 이래로 매운 음식을 좋아하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: India-e waseoneun cheoeumeuro maeun eumsigeul meogeobon iraero, maeun eumsigeul joahage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Since I first tried spicy food after coming to India, I have come to like spicy food.

examples.kr: 일어나서 이야기를 듣다 보니 이래로 소리를 내지 않게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Ireonaseo iyagireul deutda boni iraero sorireul naeji anke doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: After hearing the story when I woke up, I became so quiet that I couldn’t make a sound.

examples.kr: 건물이 불에 탄 이래로 그 곳은 빈집이 되어 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Geonmuri bule tan iraero, geu got-eun binjibi doeeo beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: Since the building was burned, it has become an empty house.

title: ~이러하다 [ireohada] (Like this, such)
short_explanation: Used to express 'like this' or 'such', indicating a certain state or condition.
long_explanation: '~이러하다' is a descriptive verb used in Korean to depict a specific state, condition, or characteristic. It is used to describe something that is 'like this' or 'in such a way'—often when directly observing or experiencing the subject.

examples.kr: 상황이 이러하니까 모두 어찌할 바를 몰랐어요.
examples.romaji: Sanghwangi ireohanikka modu eojjikal bareul mollasseoyo.
examples.en: Because the situation was like this, no one knew what to do.

examples.kr: 생각보다 문제가 이러하니 참 당황스럽네요.
examples.romaji: Saenggakboda munje-ga ireohani cham danghwangseureopneyo.
examples.en: I'm quite flustered because the problem is like this, which is unexpected.

examples.kr: 사람들이 이러하게 취급하는 것이 너무 서글픕니다.
examples.romaji: Saramdeul-i ireohage chwihaenghaneun geosi neomu seulpeumnida.
examples.en: It's really depressing that people treat me like this.

examples.kr: 그의 이러한 행동으로 인해 많은 사람들이 고통 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Geu-ui ireohan haengdong-euro inhae manheun saramdeul-i gotong badasseoyo.
examples.en: Many people have suffered due to his actions like this.

title: ~이리 [iri] (This way, like this)
short_explanation: Used to denote 'in this manner' or 'like this', often to illustrate the way something is done.
long_explanation: '~이리' is a Korean expression that indicates a specific method or manner of doing something. It is equivalent to the English expressions 'like this', 'in this way', or 'in this manner' and is frequently used in everyday conversation.

examples.kr: 그렇게 부르지 마세요, 이리 부르세요.
examples.romaji: Geureohge bureuji maseyo, iri bureuseyo.
examples.en: Don't call like that; call this way.

examples.kr: 그는 과제를 이리 해왔어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gwaje-reul iri hae wasseoyo.
examples.en: He did the assignment like this.

examples.kr: 이리 사진을 찍어 주세요.
examples.romaji: Iri sajineul jjigeo juseyo.
examples.en: Please take a picture this way.

examples.kr: 제가 이리 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jega iri hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I think I’m going to do it this way.

title: ~이미 [imi] (Already)
short_explanation: Used to express that an action has already been completed.
long_explanation: '~이미' is a particle used to denote that an action or event has already taken place. It functions similarly to the English adverb 'already' and is typically placed before the verb phrase to stress the completion of an action.

examples.kr: 저는 이미 한국어 공부를 시작했어요, 조금 늦었지만 열심히 하기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun imi hangugeo gongbureul sijakhaesseoyo, jogeum neujjiman yeolsimhi hagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I have already started studying Korean; although I am a bit late, I decided to work hard.

examples.kr: 우리는 이미 바다에 도착했어요, 더 이상 기다릴 필요가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun imi badae dochakhaesseoyo, deo isang gidaril pillyoga eopseoyo.
examples.en: We have already arrived at the sea, so there is no need to wait any longer.

examples.kr: 아이들은 이미 저녁을 먹었어요, 그래서 지금은 배가 불러요.
examples.romaji: Aideureun imi jeonyeogeul meogeosseoyo, geuraeseo jigeumeun baega bulleoyo.
examples.en: The children have already eaten dinner, so they are full now.

examples.kr: 그 영화는 이미 봤어요, 그래서 다른 걸 찾아봐야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaneun imi bwasseoyo, geuraeseo dareun geol chajabwaya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I have already seen that movie, so I think I need to look for something else.

title: ~인 바 [in ba] (Since, because it's the case that)
short_explanation: Used to express 'since' or 'because it's the case that'.
long_explanation: '~인 바' is a formal grammar form used to provide a reason or cause for something. It is similar to saying 'since' or 'because it's the case that' in English and is most often found in written or formal contexts.

examples.kr: 모임이 취소된 바 있으므로, 오늘은 집에서 쉴 생각이에요.
examples.romaji: Moim-i chwisodoen ba iss-eumyeo, oneul-eun jib-eseo swil saenggag-ieyo.
examples.en: Since the meeting has been canceled, I plan to rest at home today.

examples.kr: 그녀가 도착한 바 없으니, 아마 그녀는 우리를 기다리나 봐요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga dochakhan ba eopseuni, ama geunyeoneun uril gidarina bwayo.
examples.en: Since she hasn't arrived, she must be waiting for us.

examples.kr: 이 바이러스가 감염된 바 있는 사람들은 자가 격리를 해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: I baireoseuga gamyeomdoen ba issneun saramdeul-eun jaga gyeokrireul haeya hamnida.
examples.en: People who have been infected with this virus must self-quarantine.

examples.kr: 화장실을 사용한 바 있으니, 지금은 다른 사람이 사용할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hwajangsil-eul sayonghan ba iss-euni, jigeum-eun dareun saram-i sayonghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since the bathroom has been used, someone else can use it now.

title: ~인 이상 [in isang] (As long as, since)
short_explanation: Used to express 'as long as', 'since', or 'now that' a certain condition is met.
long_explanation: '~인 이상' sets a condition and implies that, because the condition is met, a corresponding result or action must follow. It can be translated as 'as long as', 'since', or 'now that' in English.

examples.kr: 우리가 이미 이렇게까지 온 이상, 포기하면 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Uriga imi ireohgekkaji on isang, pogihamyeon an dwaeyo.
examples.en: As long as we have come this far, we must not give up.

examples.kr: 허락받은 이상, 자유롭게 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Heorakbadeun isang, jayuropge hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since you have received permission, you can do it freely.

examples.kr: 약속을 한 이상, 꼭 지켜야 해요.
examples.romaji: Yaksogeul han isang, kkok jikyeoya haeyo.
examples.en: As long as you have made a promise, you must keep it.

examples.kr: 시험에 합격한 이상, 우리가 너를 축하해야겠어.
examples.romaji: Siheome hapgyeoghan isang, uriga neoreul chughahaeya-gesseo.
examples.en: Now that you have passed the exam, we should congratulate you.

title: ~인즉슨 [injeuksseun] (Which means, in other words)
short_explanation: Means 'which implies that' or 'in other words', used to clarify a previous statement.
long_explanation: '~인즉슨' is used to restate or clarify the premise mentioned earlier. The following clause summarizes or explains the previous information and is equivalent to 'which means that', 'implying', or 'in other words' in English.

examples.kr: 우리는 소통의 기능이 필요하다. 인즉슨, 서로의 생각을 알아야 한다는 것이다.
examples.romaji: Urineun sotong-ui gineungi pilyohada. Injeuksseun, seoro-ui saenggageul al-aya handaneun geos-ida.
examples.en: We need a means of communication. In other words, we need to understand each other’s thoughts.

examples.kr: 아버지께서는 일찍이 돌아가셨습니다. 인즉슨, 제가 아주 어렸을 때부터 부친을 잃었다는 뜻입니다.
examples.romaji: Abeojikkeseoneun iljjigi doragasyeotseumnida. Injeuksseun, jega aju eoryeosseutdae butchinueul ilheotseutaneun tteusibnida.
examples.en: My father passed away early. This means that I lost him when I was very young.

examples.kr: 그는 이 일을 담당합니다. 인즉슨, 이 일의 책임이 그에게 있다는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun i il-eul damdanghabnida. Injeuksseun, i il-ui chaegimi geuege ittdaneun geos-ida.
examples.en: He is in charge of this work. In other words, the responsibility for this work lies with him.

examples.kr: 우리는 다음 주에 시험을 봅니다. 인즉슨, 주말 동안 공부하러 도서관에 갈 필요가 있다는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun daeum juae siheomeul bobnida. Injeuksseun, jumaldongan gongbuhareo doseogwan-e gal pilyoga ittdaneun geos-ida.
examples.en: We will have an exam next week. In other words, we need to go to the library to study during the weekend.

title: ~일 리가 없다 [il riga eopda] (Cannot be, it's not possible that)
short_explanation: Expresses disbelief or denial, indicating that something is impossible.
long_explanation: '~일 리가 없다' is used to strongly deny or reject the possibility of a situation or action. It is often translated as 'there's no way that...', 'it cannot be that...', or 'it's impossible that...'.

examples.kr: 그가 그런 일을 하다니, 그럴 수가 없어요. 그런 일을 할 리가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga geureon ireul hadani, geureol su ga eopseoyo. Geureon ileul hal riga eopseoyo.
examples.en: That he did such a thing is impossible; there's no way he could have done it.

examples.kr: 너무 잘 알고 있는 그 사람이 거짓말을 할 일이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu jal algo issneun geu sarami geojinmaleul hal iri eopseoyo.
examples.en: The person I know so well would never lie.

examples.kr: 오늘은 너무 바빠서 영화를 즐길 일이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun neomu bappaseo yeonghwareul jeulgil iri eopseoyo.
examples.en: I'm too busy today; there's no way I can enjoy a movie.

examples.kr: 이런 비싼 차를 살 일이 없어요, 돈이 그리 많지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Ireon bissan chareul sal iri eopseoyo, doni geuri manhji anhayo.
examples.en: There's no way I would buy such an expensive car; I don't have that much money.

title: ~일수록 [ilsulok] (The more ~, the more ~)
short_explanation: Used to express proportional relationships; 'the more ____, the more ____'.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~일수록' denotes a proportional relationship between two states or actions. It is used when an increase or decrease in one aspect leads to a corresponding change in another, translating to 'the more ____, the more ____' in English.

examples.kr: 시간이 갈수록 나는 그를 더 많이 그리워했습니다, 그래서 우리가 함께한 장소를 방문하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Sigani galsurok naneun geureul deo manhi geuriwohaetseumnida, geuraeseo uriga hamkkehan jangsoreul bangmunhage doeeotseumnida.
examples.en: The more time passed, the more I missed him, so I ended up visiting the place where we were together.

examples.kr: 내가 한국어를 많이 연습할수록, 내 발음이 더 좋아져서 한국 사람들이 저를 더 잘 이해할 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Naega hangugeoreul manhi yeonseubhalsurok, nae baleumi deo joajyeoseo hanguk saramdeuri jeoreul deo jal ihaehal su isseotseumnida.
examples.en: The more I practiced Korean, the better my pronunciation became, and Korean people could understand me better.

examples.kr: 스프링롤을 튀길수록, 그것들은 더욱 바삭바삭해져서 맛있어졌어요.
examples.romaji: Seupeuringrolleul twigilsurok, geugeotdeureun deouk basakbasakhaejyeoseo masisseojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The more the spring rolls were fried, the crispier and tastier they became.

examples.kr: 경제가 더 나빠질수록 사람들이 고민이 더 많아져서 진로를 어떻게 결정해야 할지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Gyeongjega deo nappajilsurok saramdeuri gominhi deo manhajyeoseo jinloreul eotteohge gyeoljeonghaeya halji moreugesseumnida.
