examples.en: As the economy worsens, people have more worries and I don’t know how to decide on a career path.

title: ~지 않을테니 [ji anheulteni] (Won't, wouldn't)
short_explanation: Used to express that something will not happen or be done.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~지 않을테니' is used in casual situations to predict or assure that a certain action will certainly not occur. It conveys the speaker’s confident belief that the stated event will not happen, and is often used to advise or reassure the listener.

examples.kr: 밥은 식지 않을테니 천천히 오세요.
examples.romaji: Bap-eun sikji anheulteni cheoncheonhi oseyo.
examples.en: The food won't get cold, so come slowly.

examples.kr: 날씨가 더워지 않을테니 오늘은 긴팔을 입을 필요가 없을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga deowoji anheulteni oneuleun ginpal-eul ibeul pillyoga eopseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: The weather won't get hotter today, so there's no need to wear long sleeves.

examples.kr: 이 문제는 너무 어렵지 않을테니 걱정하지 마세요.
examples.romaji: I munjeneun neomu eoryeopji anheulteni geokjeonghaji maseyo.
examples.en: This problem won't be too hard, so don't worry.

examples.kr: 그는 너를 찾지 않을테니 안심하세요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun neoreul chatji anheulteni ansimhaseyo.
examples.en: He won't look for you, so don't worry.

title: ~지만 [jimyeon] (But, although)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or exception; 'but', 'although'.
long_explanation: '~지만' is a conjunction used in Korean to introduce a contrasting idea or an exception to the preceding statement. It is equivalent to 'but' or 'although' in English and simply connects two clauses without implying a strong adversative relationship.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋지만 바람이 너무 많이 불어서 소풍 가기에는 힘들어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joajiman barami neomu manhi bulleoseo sopung gagineun himdeureoyo.
examples.en: The weather is nice today, but the wind is blowing too much, so it's hard to go on a picnic.

examples.kr: 그 영화가 재미있었지만 너무 길어서 지루했어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaga jaemiisseossjiman neomu gireoseo jiruhaesseoyo.
examples.en: The movie was interesting, but it was too long, so it was boring.

examples.kr: 친구가 농담을 했지만 아무도 웃지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga nongdameul haessjiman amudo usji anhassseoyo.
examples.en: My friend made a joke, but nobody laughed.

examples.kr: 그 점심이 맛있었지만 너무 비싸서 다시 가기 싫어요.
examples.romaji: Geus jeomsimi masisseossjiman neomu bissaseo dasi gagi sirheoyo.
examples.en: The lunch was delicious, but it was too expensive, so I don't want to go there again.

title: ~지 않다/지 못하다 [ji anhda/ji mothada] (Not, don't, can't)
short_explanation: Used to express negation (do not) or inability (cannot).
long_explanation: '~지 않다' is used to indicate that one does not or does not intend to perform an action, while '~지 못하다' expresses an inability to perform an action. The former is used for intentional negation, and the latter when one is prevented or unable to do something.
formation: Verb Stem + 지 않다 / Verb Stem + 지 못하다

examples.kr: 우리는 그 레스토랑에서 마음에 드는 음식을 찾지 못했어요, 그래서 다른 레스토랑을 찾아보기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun geu reseutorangeseo maeume deuneun eumsigeul chajji mothaseoyo, geuraeseo dareun reseutorangeul chajabogiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: We couldn't find food we liked in that restaurant, so we decided to look for another one.

examples.kr: 그 학생은 그 문제를 이해하지 않아서 선생님에게 또 질문했어요.
examples.romaji: Geu haksaengeun geu munjeleul ihaehaji anhaseo seonsaengnimege tto jilmunhaesseoyo.
examples.en: That student did not understand the problem, so they asked the teacher again.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 늦게 집에 돌아오지 않을 거예요, 왜냐하면 아직 해야 할 일이 있기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bame neutge jibe doraoji anheul geoyeyo, waenamyon ajig haeya hal iri issgi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: I won't come home late tonight because I still have things to do.

examples.kr: 영화도 보지 못하고, 책도 읽지 못했어요. 너무 바빴어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwado boji mothago, chaekdo ilgji mothasseoyo. Neomu bappasseoyo.
examples.en: I couldn't watch a movie or read a book because I was too busy.

title: ~지 얼마나 되다 [ji eolmana dweda] (How long has it been)
short_explanation: Used to ask or state the duration since an event occurred.
long_explanation: '~지 얼마나 되다' is a construction used to inquire about or indicate the amount of time that has passed since a certain event took place. It literally asks 'how long has it been' and is useful when discussing past events or experiences.
formation: Verb (in past tense) + 지 + 얼마나 되다

examples.kr: 우리가 마지막으로 만난 후 지난 시간이 얼마나 되었나요?
examples.romaji: Uriga majimag-eulo mannan hu jinan sigani eolmana doeeossnayo?
examples.en: How long has it been since we last met?

examples.kr: 너는 서울에 온 지 얼마나 되었어?
examples.romaji: Neoneun seoul-e on ji eolmana doeeosseo?
examples.en: How long has it been since you came to Seoul?

examples.kr: 그 책을 읽은 지 얼마나 되었나요?
examples.romaji: Geu chaegeul ilgeun ji eolmana doeeossnayo?
examples.en: How long has it been since you read that book?

examples.kr: 저는 한국에 온 지 얼마나 되었는데 아직도 한국말이 어렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hanguk-e on ji eolmana doeeossneunde ajikdo hangukmali eoryeopseubnida.
examples.en: It's been a while since I came to Korea, but Korean is still difficult for me.

title: ~지요/죠 [jiyo/jyo] (Isn't it, right)
short_explanation: Used at the end of a sentence to seek agreement or confirmation.
long_explanation: '~지요/죠' is an ending used in Korean to ask for confirmation or agreement from the listener. It suggests that the speaker expects the listener to share the same view or to confirm the statement, and it is often employed in polite or formal contexts.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 참 좋지요?
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga cham joahjiyo?
examples.en: The weather is really nice today, isn't it?

examples.kr: 그 영화 정말 재미있었지요?
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwa jeongmal jaemiisseotjiyo?
examples.en: That movie was really interesting, right?

examples.kr: 내일도 여기서 만나는 거죠?
examples.romaji: Naeildo yeogiseo mannaneun geojyo?
examples.en: We're meeting here again tomorrow, right?

examples.kr: 이 방법이 맞는 거 같지요?
examples.romaji: I bangbeobi matneun geo gatjiyo?
examples.en: This method seems correct, doesn't it?

title: ~쯤 [jjeum] (About, around)
short_explanation: Used to indicate approximations or rough estimates.
long_explanation: '~쯤' is a postposition used in Korean to give an approximate amount, time, or degree. It is commonly paired with numbers or measurements to express 'about' or 'around' in informal speech.

examples.kr: 비행기가 적어도 3시간쯤 지연될 것 같아요, 그래서 걱정이 돼요.
examples.romaji: Bihaeng-giga jeogeodo 3 sigan jjeum jiyeondoel geot gatayo, geuraeseo geogjeong-i dwaeyo.
examples.en: It looks like the plane will be delayed for about 3 hours, so I'm worried.

examples.kr: 우리는 오늘 회사에 서른 명쯤이 왔어요, 그래서 많은 일을 맡았어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun oneul hoesae seoreun myeong jjeumi wasseoyo, geuraeseo maneun ileul matasseoyo.
examples.en: About thirty people came to the company today, so we have a lot of work.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 한 시간쯤 일찍 와서 준비를 해요, 그래서 다른 사람들보다 항상 더 빨리 끝나요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang han sigan jjeum iljjik wasseo junbireul haeyo, geuraeseo dareun saramdeulboda hangsang deo ppalli kkeutnayo.
examples.en: He always comes about an hour early to prepare, so he always finishes faster than others.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에 여행을 계획하고 있어서 오늘은 한 시간쯤 일찍 퇴근하려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumal-e yeohaeng-eul gyehoekhago isseoseo oneul-eun han sigan jjeum iljjik toegeunharyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I'm planning a trip this weekend, so I'm trying to leave work about an hour early today.

title: ~처럼 [cheoreom] (Like, as)
short_explanation: Used to express similarity or comparison; 'like', 'as'.
long_explanation: '~처럼' is used in Korean to compare or show similarity between two things. It indicates that someone or something is similar in appearance, behavior, or quality to another.

examples.kr: 그녀는 나비처럼 춤을 추었습니다. 아름답고 가벼워 보였어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nabicheoreom chumeul chueossseubnida. Areumdapgo gabyeoweo boyeosseoyo.
examples.en: She danced like a butterfly, looking beautiful and light.

examples.kr: 그는 마치 세계적인 테니스 선수처럼 쳤어요. 그의 기술이 정말 뛰어났어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun machi segyejeogin teniseu seonsucheoreom chyeosseoyo. Geuui gisuli jeongmal ttwieonatsseoyo.
examples.en: He hit like a world-class tennis player; his skills were truly outstanding.

examples.kr: 당신은 천사처럼 친절해요. 항상 남을 도와주려고 노력하죠.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun cheonsacheoreom chinjeolhaeyo. Hangsang nameul dowajuryeogo noryeokhajyo.
examples.en: You're kind like an angel, always trying to help others.

examples.kr: 이 새초롬이 정원의 꽃들처럼 화려합니다. 그것들은 진짜로 생동감 넘치는 색을 가지고 있어요.
examples.romaji: I saechoromi jeongwon-ui kkotdeulcheoreom hwaryeohapnida. Geugeotdeureun jinjjaro saengdonggam neomchineun saegeul gajigo isseoyo.
examples.en: These prints are as vibrant as the flowers in the garden—they have truly lively colors.

title: ~치고는 [chigoneun] (For, considering)
short_explanation: Used to express a comparison against a standard; 'for' or 'considering'.
long_explanation: '~치고는' is a suffix used to compare a subject to what is normally expected of it. It indicates that, considering the usual standards, the result is surprisingly good or bad. It is often translated as 'for (a ...)' or 'considering (that ...)' in English.

examples.kr: 어린이 치고는 그림 그리는 실력이 아주 탁월해요.
examples.romaji: Eorini chigoneun geurim geurineun sillryeogi aju takweolhaeyo.
examples.en: For a child, his drawing skills are exceptional.

examples.kr: 기초 수업 치고는 너무 어려워서 모든 학생들이 혼란스러웠어요.
examples.romaji: Gicho sueop chigoneun neomu eoryeowoseo modeun haksengdeuri honranseureoweosseoyo.
examples.en: Considering it was just a basic class, it was so difficult that all the students were confused.

examples.kr: 이렇게 짧은 시간 치고는 많은 일을 처리한 게 놀라워요.
examples.romaji: Ileohge jjalbeun sigan chigoneun manheun ileul cheolihan ge nollawoyo.
examples.en: For such a short time, it's amazing how much work was done.

examples.kr: 비록 초보자 치고는 당신이 상당히 잘하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Birok choboja chigoneun dangsini sangdanghi jalhago isseoyo.
examples.en: Considering you're a beginner, you're doing pretty well.

title: ~테니라고 [tenirago] (Since, because)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a reason or cause; 'since' or 'because'.
long_explanation: The form '~테니라고' in the provided entry is nonstandard in contemporary Korean. In modern usage the common and natural form is '~테니까'. This ending is used to give a reason or justification for a situation or action. I have changed all instances to '~테니까' so that the explanation and examples match current usage.

examples.kr: 너무 오래 걸리는 일이라서 그냥 제가 했어요. 괜히 기다렸다가 다른 일에 지체될 테니까 생각했어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu orae geollineun iriraseo geunyang jegado haesseoyo. Gwaenhi gidaryeossdaga dareun ire jicheodwael tenikka saenggakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I did it myself because it takes too long; I thought that waiting would only delay other work.

examples.kr: 이길 테니까 자신감을 가져보세요. 성공의 비결은 자신감이에요.
examples.romaji: Igill tenikka jasin gameul gajyeoboseyo. Seonggong-ui bigyeol-eun jasinyimieyo.
examples.en: Have confidence because you'll win. The secret to success is confidence.

examples.kr: 너무 많이 먹으면 안 돼. 소화가 잘 안 될 테니까 주의해야 돼.
examples.romaji: Neomu mani meogeumyeon an dwae. Sowaga jal an doel tenikka juuihaeya dwae.
examples.en: You shouldn't eat too much because it might not digest well.

examples.kr: 그 과자는 너무 달아서 안 좋아. 너무 달면 양치가 상할 테니까 생각해서 안 먹었어.
examples.romaji: Geu gwaja neun neomu daraseo an johahanda. Neomu damyeon yangchiga sang hal tenikka saenggak haeseo an meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I don't like that snack because it's too sweet—I didn't eat it since I thought it would harm my teeth.

title: ~텐데 [tende] (Would, might)
short_explanation: Used to express a hypothetical situation or expectation; 'would', 'might'.
long_explanation: '~텐데' is used to express a hypothetical situation, expectation, assumption, or prediction. It indicates that under certain conditions an action or state would or might occur. Often, it is used to imply a consequence if a condition were met.

examples.kr: 오늘 당신이 오지 않았다면, 저는 화가 나텐데 다행히 당신이 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul dangsini oji anatdamyeon, jeoneun hwaga natende, dahaenghi dangsini wasseoyo.
examples.en: If you hadn't come today, I would have been angry, but luckily you came.

examples.kr: 모르는 사람들하고 말을 하지 않으려고 했으면, 언어를 배우는 것이 어려텐데 다행히 내가 그런 사람이 아니에요.
examples.romaji: Moreuneun saramdeulhago mareul haji aneulyeogo haesseumyeon, eoneoreul baeuneun geosi eoryeotende, dahaenghi naega geureon sarami anieyo.
examples.en: If I were the type who didn't want to talk to strangers, learning a language would be difficult, but luckily I'm not that kind of person.

examples.kr: 당신이 나에게 거짓말을 하지 않았다면, 나는 실망했을 텐데 다행히 당신은 솔직했어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini naege geojitmaleul haji anatdamyeon, naneun silmanghaesseul tende, dahaenghi dangsineun soljikhaesseoyo.
examples.en: If you hadn't lied to me, I would have been disappointed, but luckily you were honest.

examples.kr: 제가 당신을 만나지 못했다면, 제가 한국어를 배우는 것이 어렵게 했을 텐데 당신 덕분에 한국어를 잘 배울 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Jega dangsineul mannaji mothaetdamyeon, jega hangugeoreul baeuneun geosi eoryeopge haesseul tende, dangsin deokbune hangugeoreul jal baeul su isseosseoyo.
examples.en: If I hadn't met you, learning Korean would have been difficult, but thanks to you, I was able to learn Korean well.

title: ~토록 [torok] (So ~ that, to the extent)
short_explanation: Used to express the extent or degree of a condition or state.
long_explanation: '~토록' is used to indicate the degree or extent of a situation, often to emphasize that something is so extreme or intense that it produces a particular result. It can be translated as 'so ... that' or 'to the extent that' in English.

examples.kr: 그의 음악을 들어본 사람들은 모두 그가 어떻게 그런 멋진 음악을 만들 수 있는지를 이해하지 못할 정도로 그의 음악에 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Geuui eumageul deureobon saramdeureun modu geuga eotteoke geureon meotjin eumageul mandeul su issneunji-reul ihaehaji mothal jeongdoro geuui eumage nollaesseoyo.
examples.en: Everyone who listened to his music was so amazed that they couldn’t understand how he could create such fantastic music.

examples.kr: 건물이 너무 높아서 바닥을 볼 정도로 몸이 떨렸어요.
examples.romaji: Geonmuri neomu nopaseo badageul bol jeongdoro momi tteolleosseoyo.
examples.en: The building was so high that I trembled to the extent that I could see the floor.

examples.kr: 고등학생 때까지는 수학 문제를 풀 정도로 머리가 좋았어요.
examples.romaji: Godeunghaksaeng ttaekkajineun suhak munjereul pul jeongdoro meoriga joasseoyo.
examples.en: Until high school, I was smart enough to solve math problems.

examples.kr: 그 한국어 책이 너무 어려워서 아무런 문장도 이해하지 못할 정도예요.
examples.romaji: Geu hangugeo chaegi neomu eoryeowoseo amureon munjangdo ihaehaji mothal jeongdoeyo.
examples.en: The Korean book is so difficult that I can’t understand any of its sentences.

title: ~하게 [hage] (Make, let)
short_explanation: Used to indicate making or letting someone do something.
long_explanation: '~하게' is an ending attached to a verb root that shows someone is made to do something or is allowed to do something. It is commonly used when giving orders, making requests, or suggesting actions.

examples.kr: 선생님은 학생들이 숙제를 잘 이해하게 설명해 주었어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun hagsaengdeuri sugjereul jal ihaehage seolmyeonghae jueosseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher explained the homework so that the students could understand it well.

examples.kr: 엄마는 저에게 매일 침실을 청소하게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun jeoege maeil chimsireul cheongsohage haesseoyo.
examples.en: My mom made me clean my room every day.

examples.kr: 그는 저를 자신의 결정을 받아들이게 하려고 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jeoreul jasinyi gyeoljeongeul badadeurige haryeogo haesseoyo.
examples.en: He tried to make me accept his decision.

examples.kr: 나는 어린이들이 더 창의적으로 생각하게 하는 게임을 만들고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eorinideuri deo chang-uijeok-euro saeng-gak hage haneun geim-eul mandeulgo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to create a game that makes children think more creatively.

title: ~하고나서 [hagonaseo] (After doing)
short_explanation: Indicates that one action is completed before another begins.
long_explanation: '~하고나서' is used to show that one action is finished before starting the next. It expresses a clear sequence where the first action must be completed before the subsequent action occurs.

examples.kr: 집에 와서 샤워하고나서 공부를 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe waseo syawohagonaseo gongbureul shijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: After coming home and taking a shower, I started studying.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에서 돌아온 후에 숙제를 끝내고나서 친구를 만났어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoeseo dorawon hue sukjereul kkeutnaegonaseo chingureul mannatseoyo.
examples.en: After coming back from school and finishing my homework, I met my friend.

examples.kr: 음식을 잘게 썰고나서 조리를 시작했습니다.
examples.romaji: Eumsigeul jalgae sseolgona-seo jorireul shijakhaetseumnida.
examples.en: After finely chopping the food, I started cooking.

examples.kr: 운동하고나서 가볍게 샤워하고 밥을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Undonghagonaseo gabyeopge syawohago babeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: After exercising, I took a light shower and ate a meal.

title: ~하고는 [hagoneun] (And then, after)
short_explanation: Connects sequential actions in chronological order.
long_explanation: '~하고는' is used to join two or more actions in the order in which they occur. It indicates that the first action is followed by the second and is equivalent to 'and then' or 'after' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 일어나서 운동하고는 샤워를 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achim ireonaseo undonghagoneun syaworeul hamnida.
examples.en: Every morning, I wake up, exercise, and then take a shower.

examples.kr: 그녀는 책을 읽고는 쓰기를 연습합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun chaeg-eul ilgeoneun sseugireul yeonseubhhabnida.
examples.en: She reads books and then practices writing.

examples.kr: 그는 학교에 가서 수업을 듣고는 공부를 합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hakgyoe gaseo sueobeul deudgo-neun gongbureul hamnida.
examples.en: He goes to school, attends classes, and then studies.

examples.kr: 우리는 비행기를 타고 서울에 도착하고는 휴식을 취했습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun bihaenggireul tago Seoul-e dochakha-neun hyusigeul chwihaetseumnida.
examples.en: We took a flight, arrived in Seoul, and then rested.

title: ~하구나 [haguna] (Oh, so it's)
short_explanation: Expresses a sudden realization or understanding.
long_explanation: '~하구나' is used when the speaker suddenly realizes or understands something that was previously obvious or unnoticed. It conveys surprise or enlightenment.

examples.kr: 바빠서 연락이 안 돼는 거였구나, 그럴 수 있지.
examples.romaji: Bappaseo yeollagi an dwaeneun geosyeossgeuna, geureol su issji.
examples.en: Oh, so it was because he was busy that he couldn’t contact me; that makes sense.

examples.kr: 내가 오늘 행복하다고 느낀 이유는 바로 그거였구나, 날씨가 좋아서였어.
examples.romaji: Naega oneul haengbokhadago neukkin iyuneun baro geugeosyeossgeuna, nalssiga joaseoseosseo.
examples.en: Oh, so that's why I felt happy today—it was because the weather was good.

examples.kr: 오, 이렇게 하는 거였구나! 이해가 다 되었어.
examples.romaji: Oh, ireohge haneun geoyeossgeuna! Ihaega da doeeosseo.
examples.en: Oh, so this is how it's done! Now I understand everything.

examples.kr: 진짜로 그 사람이 너를 좋아하는 거였구나, 몰랐어.
examples.romaji: Jinjaro geu sarami neoreul joahaneun geosyeossgeuna, mollasseo.
examples.en: Oh, so that person really did like you—I didn't know.

title: ~하다가 [hadaga] (While doing, was doing)
short_explanation: Indicates that one was in the middle of doing something when another event occurred.
long_explanation: '~하다가' is used to show that an action was ongoing when it was interrupted or when another action occurred. It is equivalent to 'while doing' or 'was doing' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 책을 읽다가 너무 졸려서 잠이 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chaekeul ilgeodaga neomu jollyeoseo jam-i deuleosseoyo.
examples.en: I fell asleep while reading a book because I was too sleepy.

examples.kr: 그는 게임을 하다가 엄마에게 잠깐 멈추라고 명령을 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geimeul hadaga eommage jamkkan meomchureul myeonglyeong-eul badasseoyo.
examples.en: He was playing a game when his mother ordered him to stop for a while.

examples.kr: 친구와 이야기하다가 갑자기 벨이 울려서 대화를 중단했어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa iyagi hadaga gabjagi beli ullyeosseoyo, daehwareul jungdanhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I was talking with my friend when suddenly the bell rang and we had to stop our conversation.

examples.kr: 나는 공부하다가 흥미로운 기사를 보고 읽기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun gongbuhadaga heungmireoun gisa-reul bogo ilkgi shijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I was studying when I saw an interesting article and started reading it.

title: ~하다못해 [hadamothae] (To the extent that)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize an extreme degree or state; 'to the extent that'.
long_explanation: '~하다못해' emphasizes that something is so extreme or severe that the outcome is unexpected. It is often used to underscore a negative or surprising result and can be translated as 'to the extent that' in English.

examples.kr: 그의 연설은 지루하다못해 사람들이 잠들어 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Geuui yeonseoreun jiruhadamothae saramdeuri jamdeureo beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: His speech was so boring that people fell asleep.

examples.kr: 이 작은 마을은 한산하다못해 사람한테 불그스럼 다니다보니 외로워요.
examples.romaji: I jag-eun maeureun hansanhadamothae saramhante bulgeuseureom danidaboni oeroweoyo.
examples.en: This small village is so quiet that walking around feels extremely lonely.

examples.kr: 오늘 너무 피곤하다못해 집에 도착하자마자 잠이 들었어.
examples.romaji: Oneul neomu pigonhadamothae jibe dochak hajamaja jam-i deureoseo.
examples.en: I was so tired today that I fell asleep as soon as I got home.

examples.kr: 그녀의 음식은 맛이 없다못해 사람들이 다 먹지 못하고 남겼어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoui eumsikeun masi eopdamothae saramdeuri da meokji mothago namgyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Her food was so tasteless that people left it uneaten.

title: ~하던 중에 [hadeon junge] (While I was doing)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that something happened while another action was in progress.
long_explanation: '~하던 중에' is used to describe an event that occurs during the course of another ongoing action. It is similar to saying 'while I was doing' or 'in the middle of doing' in English.

examples.kr: 책을 읽던 중에 친구가 전화해서 놀러 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Chaeg-eul ilgeodeon junge chinguga jeonhwahayeo nolleo wasseoyo.
examples.en: While I was reading a book, my friend called and came to play.

examples.kr: 음악을 듣던 중에 맞는 노래를 들어서 행복했습니다.
examples.romaji: Eumageul deuddeodeon junge majneun noraereul deureo hengbokhaetseumnida.
examples.en: While I was listening to music, I heard a song that resonated with me and I was happy.

examples.kr: 드라마를 보던 중에 언니가 갑자기 집에 와서 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Deurameul bodeon junge eonni-ga gabjagi jibe wasseo nollasseoyo.
examples.en: While I was watching a drama, my older sister suddenly came home and I was surprised.

examples.kr: 운동을 하던 중에 갑자기 비가 와서 중단하고 집에 들어갔습니다.
examples.romaji: Undong-eul hadeon junge gabjagi biga wasseo jungdanhago jibe deureogatsseumnida.
examples.en: While I was exercising, it suddenly started raining so I stopped and went home.

title: ~하기는 [hagineun] (Although, but)
short_explanation: Used to express concession or a contradictory relationship; 'although', 'but'.
long_explanation: '~하기는' is a construction used in Korean to indicate a contrast or concession—acknowledging one fact while asserting that the overall conclusion differs or contradicts it. It is often used when the second clause counteracts the first.
formation: Verb stem + 기는 (attached to form a concessive clause)

examples.kr: 그 영화는 재미있기는 했지만, 너무 기대를 해서 조금 실망했어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaneun jaemiitgineun haetjiman, neomu gidaereul haeseo jogeum silmanghaesseoyo.
examples.en: Although the movie was fun, I was a bit disappointed because my expectations were too high.

examples.kr: 케이크는 맛있기는 했지만, 너무 달아서 다 먹지는 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Keikeuneun masitgineun haetjiman, neomu daraseo da meokjineun mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: While the cake was delicious, it was too sweet so I couldn't eat all of it.

examples.kr: 그는 성격이 좋기는 하지만, 조금 느린 경향이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seonggyeogi johgineun hajiman, jogeum neurin gyeonghyangi isseoyo.
examples.en: Although he is nice, he tends to be a bit slow.

examples.kr: 이 선물은 가치가 있기는 하지만, 제 복장과는 맞지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I seonmureun gachiga itgineun hajiman, je bokjanggwaneun matji anhayo.
examples.en: Although this gift is valuable, it doesn't match my outfit.

title: ~하기로 [hagiro] (Decide to)
short_explanation: Used to express a decision made to perform an action.
long_explanation: '~하기로' is used in Korean to signify a decision made to take a specific action. It indicates that one or more people have made a concrete decision to do something and is used in both casual and formal contexts.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 오후에 만나기로 결정했어요. 우리 모두의 시간이 맞아서 복잡한 일정을 조정해야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil ohue mannagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo. Uri modueui sigani majaseo bokjaphan iljeong-eul jojeonghaeya haesseoyo.
examples.en: We decided to meet tomorrow afternoon. We all had to adjust our busy schedules to make the time.

examples.kr: 저는 내년에 한국에 이사하기로 결정했어요, 그래서 지금 강력하게 한국어를 배우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naenyeone hanguge isagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo, geuraeseo jigeum gangnyeokhage hangugeoreul baeugo isseoyo.
examples.en: I decided to move to Korea next year, so I am currently studying Korean very hard.

examples.kr: 그녀는 다음 주에 결혼하기로 결정했어요, 그래서 현재 웨딩드레스를 찾고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun da-eum ju-e gyeolhon hagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo, geuraeseo hyeonjae wedding deureseureul chatgo isseoyo.
examples.en: She decided to get married next week, so she is currently looking for a wedding dress.

examples.kr: 친구들과 함께 여름에 해변에 가기로 결정했어요, 그래서 이제부터 수영복을 사려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulgwa hamkke yeoreum-e haebyeon-e gagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo, geuraeseo ijebuteo suyeongbog-eul salyeogo habnida.
examples.en: I decided with my friends to go to the beach in the summer, so I plan to buy a swimsuit from now on.

title: ~하기에 [hagie] (For)
short_explanation: Used to express reasoning or the basis for a decision; 'for', 'considering'.
long_explanation: '~하기에' indicates the reason or basis for making a judgment or decision. It can be translated as 'for', 'considering', or 'in view of' and is used when the speaker wants to explain or justify a conclusion.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋기에 산책하기 좋은 날입니다.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga johgie sancheolkhagi joheun nalimnida.
examples.en: Considering the good weather today, it's a good day for a walk.

examples.kr: 그가 공부를 잘하기에 항상 선생님의 칭찬을 받습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga gongbureul jalgihie hangsang seonsaengnimui chingchaneul badseumnida.
examples.en: Considering that he studies well, he always receives compliments from the teacher.

examples.kr: 이 도시의 교통 상황이 복잡하기에 차를 가지고 다니는 것이 어렵습니다.
examples.romaji: I dosiui gyotong sanghwangi bokjabgihie chareul gajigo danineun geosi eoryeobseumnida.
examples.en: Considering the complex traffic in this city, it is difficult to own a car.

examples.kr: 그녀가 나를 싫어하기에 더 이상 그녀에게 연락하지 않습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nareul silheogihie deo isang geunyeoege yeonraghaji anseumnida.
examples.en: Since she dislikes me, I no longer contact her.

title: ~하려고 하다 [haryeogo hada] (Try to do)
short_explanation: Used to express the intention or effort to try to do something.
long_explanation: '~하려고 하다' indicates the speaker’s plan or intention to perform an action. It is equivalent to 'try to do' in English and is formed by attaching '하려고' to the verb stem, followed by '하다'.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 스물 분씩 책을 읽으려고 해요, 그래서 독서 행위를 습관화하려고 하는 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil seumul bunsik chaek-eul ilg-eulyeogo haeyo, geulaeseo dogsuhang-wi-reul seubgwanhwa-haryeogo haneun geo-eyo.
examples.en: I try to read a book for twenty minutes every day, so I'm working on making reading a habit.

examples.kr: 그는 좋은 일자리를 찾기 위해 잡지를 읽으려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jo-eun iljali-reul chatgi wihae jabjireul ilgeulyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: He is trying to read magazines in order to find a good job.

examples.kr: 우리는 갈등을 해결하려고 서로 대화하려고 했어요, 하지만 결과적으로는 성공하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun galdeung-eul haegyeol-haryeogo seolo daehwa-haryeogo haesseoyo, hajiman gyeolgugjeog-eulo-neun seong-gonghaeji mothhaesseoyo.
examples.en: We tried to resolve the conflict by talking to each other, but ultimately we weren't successful.

examples.kr: 언니는 동생에게 수학을 가르치려고 매일 노력하려고 했어요.
examples.romaji: Eonni-neun dongsaeng-ege suhag-eul galeuchi-haryeogo maeil nolyeok-haryeogo haesseoyo.
examples.en: My older sister made an effort every day to teach math to her younger sibling.

title: ~할 때마다 [hal ttaemada] (Every time)
short_explanation: Used to express repetition; 'every time' or 'whenever'.
long_explanation: '~할 때마다' is a standard construction used to indicate that whenever a certain condition or event occurs, a specific action follows. It emphasizes the repeatability and consistency of the action.

examples.kr: 가을이 되면 나는 고향을 떠올리며 항상 노래를 부르곤 하였다.
examples.romaji: Gaeuli doemyeon naneun gohyangeul tteoollimyeo hangsang noraereul bureugon haessda.
examples.en: Every time autumn comes, I used to sing a song while thinking of my hometown.

examples.kr: 그는 그녀를 떠올릴 때마다 노트에 그녀에 대한 노래를 적곤 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geunyeoreul tteoollil ttaemada noteue geunyeoe daehan noraereul jeokgon haessseubnida.
examples.en: Every time he thought of her, he used to write a song about her in his notebook.

examples.kr: 어머니가 시험기간이 돌아올 때마다 나에게 좋은 음식을 만들어 주셨어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeoniga siheomgigani doraol ttaemada naege joheun eumsigeul mandeureo jusyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Every time the exam period came around, my mother used to make me delicious food.

examples.kr: 나는 매번 그녀를 볼 때마다 심장이 빠르게 뛰곤 했다.
examples.romaji: Naneun maebeon geunyeoreul bol ttaemada simjangi ppareuge ttwigon haessda.
examples.en: Every time I saw her, my heart used to beat fast.

title: ~하면 할수록 [hamyeon halsurok] (The more ~, the more ~)
short_explanation: Expresses that increasing one factor causes a corresponding change in another.
long_explanation: '~하면 할수록' is used to indicate a proportional relationship between two conditions or actions. It means that the more (or less) of one thing there is, the more (or less) of another occurs.

examples.kr: 날이 점점 따뜻하면 할수록 꽃들이 많이 피어나고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nari jeomjeom ttatteuthamyeon halsurok kkotdeuri mani pieonago isseoyo.
examples.en: The warmer it gets, the more flowers are blooming.

examples.kr: 공부를 많이 하면 할수록 시험 통과 확률이 높아져요.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul mani hamyeon halsurok siheom tonggwa hwangyeongi nopajyeoyo.
examples.en: The more you study, the higher your chances of passing the exam.

examples.kr: 운동을 많이 하면 할수록 건강하게 느껴져요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul mani hamyeon halsurok geonganghage neukkyeojyeoyo.
examples.en: The more I exercise, the healthier I feel.

examples.kr: 요리 연습을 하면 할수록 능력이 향상되어요.
examples.romaji: Yori yeonseubeul hamyeon halsurok neungryeogi hyangsangdoeyo.
examples.en: The more I practice cooking, the better I get at it.

title: ~하면서 [hamyeonseo] (While doing)
short_explanation: Used to describe two actions occurring simultaneously by the same subject.
long_explanation: '~하면서' is a conjunction used to indicate that two actions take place at the same time. It is equivalent to 'while' or 'as' in English and connects clauses where the same subject performs both actions.

examples.kr: 안경을 쓰면서 책을 읽었어요, 그래서 아주 편하게 읽을 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Angyeongeul sseumyeonseo chaeg-eul ilsseoss-eoyo, geulaeseo aju pyeonhage ilgeul su isseoss-eoyo.
examples.en: I read a book while wearing glasses, so I was able to read very comfortably.

examples.kr: 음악을 듣으면서 숙제를 했어요, 그래서 지루하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Eumageul deudeumyeonseo sugjeleul haess-eoyo, geulaeseo jilu-haji anh-ass-eoyo.
examples.en: I did my homework while listening to music, so it wasn't boring.

examples.kr: 카페에서 커피를 마시면서 일했어요, 그래서 아주 고요하게 집중할 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Kapeeseo keopireul masimyeonseo ilhaess-eoyo, geulaeseo aju goyohage jibjung-hal su isseoss-eoyo.
examples.en: I worked at a café while drinking coffee, so I was able to focus very well.

examples.kr: 운전을 하면서 노래 부르는 것이 아주 좋아요, 그래서 운전이 지루하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Unjeon-eul haneumyeonseo nolaereul bureuneun geosi aju joayo, geulaeseo unjeon-i jilu haji anhayo.
examples.en: It's great to drive while singing, so driving isn't boring.

title: ~하시겠습니까? [hasigesseubnikka?] (Would you?)
short_explanation: A very formal and honorific way to request, ask, or suggest something.
long_explanation: '~하시겠습니까?' is used to politely and formally request or ask a question. It is formed by adding this ending (after removing the final '-다' from the verb) and is typically used in formal or honorific situations.

examples.kr: 저녁식사를 함께 하시겠습니까?
examples.romaji: Jeonyeoksiksa-reul hamkke hasigesseubnikka?
examples.en: Would you like to have dinner together?

examples.kr: 이 문서를 검토해 주시겠습니까?
examples.romaji: I munseo-reul geomtohae jusigesseubnikka?
examples.en: Would you please review this document?

examples.kr: 이 컨퍼런스에 참석하시겠습니까?
examples.romaji: I keonpeoreonseue chamseokhasigesseubnikka?
examples.en: Would you attend this conference?

examples.kr: 제안을 고려해 주시겠습니까?
examples.romaji: Jeahneul goryeohae jusigesseubnikka?
examples.en: Would you consider the proposal?

title: ~하자 [haja] (Let's, as soon as)
short_explanation: Used to suggest an action or express immediate action following another.
long_explanation: '~하자' is a conjugated form of '하다' used in two ways: to make suggestions (equivalent to 'let's') and to indicate that one action will immediately follow another (as in 'as soon as'). It is commonly used in conversational Korean.
formation: Verb stem + 자 (for suggestion) / Verb stem + 자마자 (for 'as soon as')

examples.kr: 날씨가 정말 좋으니까, 우리 나가서 산책하자.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga jeongmal joeunikka, uri nagaseo sancheonghaja.
examples.en: The weather is really good, so let's go out for a walk.

examples.kr: 저녁 먹자마자 친구에게 전화해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonyeok meokjamaja chinguege jeonhwahaeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: I have to call my friend as soon as I finish dinner.

examples.kr: 시험이 끝나자마자 여행가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi kkeutnajamaja yeohaenggago sipeoyo.
examples.en: I want to travel as soon as the exam is over.

examples.kr: 이 영화를 보자, 후회하지 않을 거예요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaleul boja, huhoehaji anheul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Let's watch this movie; you won't regret it.

title: ~하여 [hayeo] (So, therefore)
short_explanation: Used to express reason, cause, or circumstances; 'so' or 'therefore'.
long_explanation: '~하여' is a connecting ending used to show a cause-effect relationship—similar to 'so' or 'therefore' in English. It introduces a clause that explains the reason or cause for the preceding statement and is generally used in formal or written contexts.

examples.kr: 저는 늦게 일어나하여 학교에 늦게 도착했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun neujge ileonahayeo hakgyoe neujge dochakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I woke up late, so I arrived late at school.

examples.kr: 그녀는 너무 피곤했어서 더 이상 일어날 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun neomu pigonhayeo deo isang ileonal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: She was so tired that she could no longer get up.

examples.kr: 회사에서 일하느라 너무 바빴어서, 친구들과의 약속을 취소해야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseo ilhaneura neomu bappaseo, chingudeulgwa-ui yaksogeul chwisohayeo haesseoyo.
examples.en: I was so busy at work that I had to cancel my appointment with friends.

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 추웠어서, 외출을 하지 않고 집에 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu chuwoseo, oechuleul haji anhgo jibe isseosseoyo.
examples.en: The weather was so cold that I didn't go out and stayed home.

title: ~하여야 [hayeoya] (Have to, should)
short_explanation: Used to express the necessity or obligation; 'have to', 'should'.
long_explanation: '~하여야' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate that a certain action is necessary or obligatory—often used in contexts of duty, responsibility, or advice. It corresponds to 'have to', 'should', or 'must' in English, imparting a sense of expectation upon the subject.

examples.kr: 공부를 열심히 해야 성적이 좋아질 거예요, 그래서 매일 열심히 공부해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul yeolsimhi haeya seongjeogi joajilgeoyeyo, geuraeseo maeil yeolsimhi gongbuhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: You have to study hard to get good grades, so you should study hard every day.

examples.kr: 요리를 잘하기 위해서 재료들을 미리 준비하여야 합니다, 그렇기 때문에 주방에서 일찍 시작하여야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Yorireul jalhagi wihaeseo jaeryodeureul miri junbihayeoya hamnida, geureohgi ttaemune jubangeseo iljjik sijakhayeoya hamnida.
examples.en: To cook well, you need to prepare ingredients in advance, so you should start early in the kitchen.

examples.kr: 운동을 매일 하여야 건강을 유지할 수 있어요, 그러므로 매일 아침에 산책하여야 해요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul maeil hayeya geongangeul yujihal su isseoyo, geureomeuro maeil achime sancaekhayeya haeyo.
examples.en: You have to exercise every day to maintain good health, so you should take a walk every morning.

examples.kr: 교통사고를 막기 위해서는 법규를 잘 지켜야 하고, 또한 조심하여야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Gyotongsagoreul maggi wihaeseoneun beomgyureul jal jikyeoya hago, ttohan joshimhayeya hamnida.
examples.en: To prevent traffic accidents, you should abide by the laws and also be careful.

title: ~하자마자 [hajamaja] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Used to express 'as soon as' or 'immediately after'.
long_explanation: '~하자마자' is a conjugational pattern in Korean used to indicate that one action occurs immediately after another. It is roughly equivalent to 'as soon as' in English, showing prompt succession of events.

examples.kr: 저는 그의 편지를 받자마자 그에게 전화를 걸었습니다, 전혀 늦추지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun geuui pyeonjireul badjamaja geuege jeonhwaleul georeosseoyo, jeonhyeo neujchuji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I received his letter, I called him without any delay.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에서 돌아오자마자 숙제를 시작했습니다, 아무런 휴식 시간도 없었습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoeseo doraojamaja sukjereul shijakhaesseoyo, amureon hyusik sigan-do eopseumnida.
examples.en: As soon as I returned from school, I started my homework without any break.

examples.kr: 영화가 끝나자마자 그들은 영화관에서 나갔습니다, 다른 일정이 있었기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwaga kkeutnajamaja geudeureun yeonghwagwaneseo nagassseumnida, dareun iljeongi isseossgi ttaemunimnida.
examples.en: As soon as the movie ended, they left the theater because they had other plans.

examples.kr: 엄마가 집에 돌아오자마자 강아지는 기뻐하며 점프했습니다, 엄마를 정말 사랑하는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga jibe doraojamaja gangajineun gippeohamyeo jeompeuhaesseoyo, eommareul jeongmal saranghaneun geot gatayo.
examples.en: As soon as mom returned home, the puppy jumped happily—it really seems to love her.

title: ~하여 [hayeo] (So, therefore)
short_explanation: Used to express a cause–effect relationship; 'so', 'therefore'.
long_explanation: '~하여' is a connecting ending used in Korean to indicate the cause or reason for a situation, similar to 'so' or 'therefore' in English. It is typically used in formal or written contexts.

examples.kr: 저는 늦게 일어나하여 학교에 늦게 도착했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun neujge ileonahayeo hakgyoe neujge dochakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I woke up late, so I arrived late at school.

examples.kr: 그녀는 너무 피곤하여 더 이상 일어날 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun neomu pigonhayeo deo isang ileonal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: She was so tired that she could no longer get up.

examples.kr: 교통체증이 심하여 버스가 늦게 도착했어요.
examples.romaji: Gyotongchejeomi simhayeo beoseuga neujge dochakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Due to heavy traffic, the bus arrived late.

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 추워하여 밖에 나가기 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu chuwoseo bakk-e nagagi eoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: The weather was so cold that it was hard to go outside.

title: ~하기보다 [hagiboda] (Rather than)
short_explanation: Used to express comparison or contrast; 'rather than', 'instead of'.
long_explanation: '~하기보다' is used in Korean to compare two alternatives, expressing a preference or contrast between them. It is roughly translated as 'rather than' or 'instead of' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 집에서 영화를 보는 것보다 극장에서 보는 것을 더 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jibeseo yeonghwareul boneun geotboda geukjangeseo boneun geoseul deo joahaeyo.
examples.en: I like watching movies at the theater more than watching them at home.

examples.kr: 과일을 먹기보다는 차라리 샐러드를 먹는 게 더 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Gwaireul meokgibodaneun charari saelleodeureul meokneun ge deo joayo.
examples.en: I'd rather eat a salad than eat fruit.

examples.kr: 친구와 식당에서 점심을 먹기보다, 집에서 직접 만든 음식을 먹는 것이 더 낫다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa sikdangeseo jeomsimeul meokgibodaneun, jibeseo jikjeob mandeun eumsigeul meokneun geosi deo natdago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I think it's better to eat food made at home than to have lunch at a restaurant with friends.

examples.kr: TV를 보기보다는 책을 읽는 것이 더 도움이 됩니다.
examples.romaji: TVreul bogibodaneun chaeg-eul ilgneun geosi deo doum-i doebnida.
examples.en: Reading a book is more helpful than watching TV.

title: ~하느라 [haneura] (Because of doing, due to)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that being busy doing something has led to a certain (often negative) consequence.
long_explanation: '~하느라' is used in Korean to explain that one was so busy doing something that it caused another result—typically an unintended negative outcome. It is often translated as 'because of doing' or 'due to being busy with'.

examples.kr: 준비를 하느라 시간이 많이 걸렸어요.
examples.romaji: Junbireul haneura sigani mani geollyeosseoyo.
examples.en: It took a lot of time because I was preparing.

examples.kr: 시험 공부를 하느라 친구들과 만나지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom gongbureul haneura chingudeulgwa mannaji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I couldn't meet my friends because I was studying for the exam.

examples.kr: 사업 때문에 열심히 일하느라 몸이 많이 지쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Saebe ttaemune yeolsimhi ilhaneura momi mani jichyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I got very exhausted because I was working hard for my business.

examples.kr: 뜨거운 여름날에, 그녀는 아이스크림 가게를 관리하느라 바빴습니다.
examples.romaji: Ddeugeoun yeoreumnarae, geunyeoneun aiseukeurim gagerul gwanlihaneura bappatsseumnida.
examples.en: On a hot summer day, she was busy managing an ice-cream shop.

title: ~하는 한 [haneun han] (As long as)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the condition or basis on which something can happen or be established; 'as long as'.
long_explanation: '~하는 한 [haneun han]' is used in Korean to emphasize the condition or requirement necessary for something to happen. It is equivalent to the English phrase 'as long as', indicating that something will or can happen on the premise of the condition specified. This is frequently used in situations requiring adherence to a certain condition or meeting a particular prerequisite.

examples.kr: 너는 공부하는 한 항상 성공할 수 있을 거야.
examples.romaji: Neoneun gongbuhaneun han hangsang seonggonghal su isseul geoya.
examples.en: As long as you study, you will always be able to succeed.

examples.kr: 우리는 서로에게 솔직하게 말하는 한 아무런 문제가 없을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun seoroege soljikhage malhaneun han amureon munjega eopseul geos-ibnida.
examples.en: As long as we speak honestly to each other, there will be no problem.

examples.kr: 부모님의 지시를 따르는 한 우리집에서는 어떤 일도 문제가 되지 않아.
examples.romaji: Bumonim-ui jishireul ttareuneun han urijib-eseoneun eotteon il-do munjega doji ana.
examples.en: As long as you follow your parents' instructions, nothing will be a problem in our house.

examples.kr: 당신이 재능을 발휘하는 한, 이 일에 대해 좌절할 필요가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini jaeneung-eul balhwihaneun han, i ile daehae jwajeolhal pil-yoga eobseoyo.
examples.en: As long as you use your talent, there's no need to be frustrated about this job.

title: ~하는 김에 [haneun kime] (While at it)
short_explanation: This is used to express 'while doing A, do B', or 'since you are doing A, might as well do B'.
long_explanation: ~하는 김에 [haneun kime] is a Korean grammatical expression used to present additional actions you might as well do while you're in the process of doing a primary action. This commonly translates to 'while doing it, might as well do B' or 'since you're doing it, also do B'. It also suggests that the secondary action (B) may be somewhat related to, or is convenient because of, the primary action (A).

examples.kr: 서점에 가는 김에 책도 사고 필요한 연필도 사왔어요.
examples.romaji: Seojeome ganeun kime chaekdo sago pilyohan yeonpildo sawasseoyo.
examples.en: While I was at the bookstore, I also bought a book and the pencils I needed.

examples.kr: 집에 가는 김에 마트에서 간식을 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe ganeun kime mateueseo gansigeul sasseoyo.
examples.en: While I was going home, I bought some snacks from the supermarket.

examples.kr: 동생이 공원에 가는 김에 나도 같이 가서 운동하려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Dongsaengi gongwon-e ganeun kime nado gati gaseo undongharyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: Since my younger sibling is going to the park, I also plan to go and exercise.

examples.kr: 친구를 만나러 가는 김에 선물을 사 줄 거예요.
examples.romaji: Chingureul mannareo ganeun kime seonmureul sa jul geoyeyo.
examples.en: While I'm going to meet a friend, I also plan to buy a gift.

title: ~하는 편이다 [haneun pyeonida] (Tend to)
short_explanation: This expression is used to describe a tendency or habit.
long_explanation: '~하는 편이다 [haneun pyeonida]' is a Korean grammar point used to express a general habit or tendency of someone or something. It is generally used to describe an action that is not absolutely consistent, but is generally favored or avoided. It can be translated as 'tend to', 'more likely to', or 'has a habit of' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 일찍 일어나는 편이에요. 이렇게 했을 때 하루를 더 효율적으로 시작할 수 있어서요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun iljjik ireonaneun pyeonieyo. Ireohge haesseul ttae harureul deo hyoyuljeogeuro sijakhal su isseoseoyo.
examples.en: I tend to wake up early. It allows me to start my day more efficiently.

examples.kr: 그녀는 여행을 갈 때 항상 사진을 많이 찍는 편이에요, 그녀는 추억을 사진으로 보관하는 것을 좋아하기 때문이죠.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeohaengeul galttae hangsang sajineul manhi jjikneun pyeonieyo, geunyeoneun chueogeul sajineuro bogwanhaneun geoseul joahagi ttaemunijyo.
examples.en: She tends to take a lot of photos when she travels because she likes to keep memories in photos.

examples.kr: 날씨가 따뜻해지면 사람들은 더 많이 운동하는 편이에요, 건강을 지키기 위해 걷거나 달리는 것을 선호하는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga ttatteushaejimyeon saramdeuleun deo mani undonghaneun pyeonieyo, geongang-eul jikigi wihae geolgeona dallineun geoseul seonhoaneun geot gatayo.
examples.en: When the weather gets warmer, people tend to exercise more; it seems they prefer walking or running to stay healthy.

examples.kr: 저는 고민이 있을 때 친구와 이야기하는 편이에요, 그들의 다양한 생각들이 항상 도움이 되니까요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gomini isseul ttae chinguwa iyagihaneun pyeonieyo, geudeurui dayanghan saenggakdeuri hangsang doum-i doeyo.
examples.en: When I have a problem, I tend to talk to my friends because their different thoughts always help.

title: ~하는 대로 [haneun daero] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Used to express 'as soon as' or 'immediately after'.
long_explanation: '~하는 대로 [haneun daero]' is a compound verb ending used to express the immediate action taken after a certain situation or event has occurred. It indicates simultaneous actions or immediate sequences, much like 'as soon as' or 'immediately after' in English. When you want to say that something happened right after something else without any time gap, you can use this ending.

examples.kr: 그의 공연이 시작하는 대로 모든 사람들이 환호를 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuui gongyeon-i sijakaneun daero modeun saramdeuli hwanhoreul sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as his performance started, everyone started cheering.

examples.kr: 일어나는 대로 양치를 해야 당신의 치아를 보호할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ireonaneun daero yangchireul haeya dangsinui chiyareul bohohal su isseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as you wake up, you should brush your teeth to protect your dental health.

examples.kr: 운동을 끝내는 대로 많은 물을 마셔요, 그래야 탈수를 피할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul kkeutnaeneun daero maneul muleul masyeoyo, geuraeya talsureul pihal su isseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as you finish exercising, drink plenty of water to avoid dehydration.

examples.kr: 비행기가 착륙하는 대로 그는 전화를 걸었어요.
examples.romaji: Bihaenggi-ga chakryukhaneun daero geuneun jeonhwaleul geolasseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as the plane landed, he made a call.

title: ~하다 보면 [hada bomyeon] (If you keep doing)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express the idea that if you keep doing something, then a certain result will eventually happen.
long_explanation: The Korean grammar point '~하다 보면 [hada bomyeon]' is used to show that if you do something continuously, it will eventually lead to a certain outcome. It implies that over time, repeating an action or behavior can bring about a specific change or effect. The verb preceding '하다 보면' expresses the action, and the pattern is often used with actions that have a progressive or accumulative effect.

examples.kr: 매일 한 단어씩 배우다 보면 한 달 후에는 새롭게 배운 단어가 30개나 됩니다.
examples.romaji: Maeil han daneo-ssik baeuda bomyeon han dal hueaneun saeropge baeun daneoga 30gaena doebnida.
examples.en: If you learn one word every day, you will have learned 30 new words after a month.

examples.kr: 계속해서 연습하다 보면 결국 능력이 향상될 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Gyesokhaeseo yeonseubhada bomyeon gyeolguk neungryeogi hyangsangdoel geosibnida.
examples.en: If you keep practicing, your skills will eventually improve.

examples.kr: 매일 충분히 운동하다 보면 몸이 건강해질 것이다.
examples.romaji: Maeil chungbunhi undonghada bomyeon momi geonganghaejil geosida.
examples.en: If you exercise enough every day, your body will become healthy.

examples.kr: 변화를 받아들이려고 노력하다 보면 어려운 상황에도 대처할 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Byeonhwaleul badadeuliryeogo noryeokhada bomyeon eoryeoun sanghwang-edo daecheohal su isseul geosibnida.
examples.en: If you try to accept change, you will be able to handle difficult situations.

title: ~하다 보니 [hada boni] (As I was doing)
short_explanation: Used to express how one thing naturally leads to another; 'as I was doing, I realized that...'.
long_explanation: '~하다 보니 [hada boni]' is used to describe a situation where, while doing something, you gradually come to realize, understand, or feel something. It is often translated as 'as I was doing, I realized that' and is used to express naturally emerging emotions or insights as a result of ongoing actions.

examples.kr: 매일 운동하다 보니 건강이 좋아져서 기분이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Maeil undonghada boni geongangi joeajyeoseo gibuni joeajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: As I exercised every day, my health improved and I felt good.

examples.kr: 한국어를 계속 공부하다 보니 한국 문화에 대해서 더 이해하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Hanguk-eoreul gyesog gongbu-hada boni Hanguk munhwa-e daehaeseo deo ihaehage doe-eosseoyo.
examples.en: As I continued to study Korean, I came to understand Korean culture better.

examples.kr: 요리를 자주 하다 보니 집에서 먹는 음식이 더 맛있게 느껴져서 더 자주 요리하게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul jagu hada boni jib-eseo meogneun eumsigi do masitge neukkyeo-jyeoseo deo jagu yori-hage dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: As I cooked more often, the food at home started tasting better, so I began cooking more frequently.

examples.kr: 나는 친구들과 많은 시간을 보내다 보니 그들과 더 친밀해진 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingudeulgwa manheun siganeul bonaeda boni geudeul-gwa deo chinmilhaejin geos gat-ayo.
examples.en: As I spent a lot of time with my friends, I feel that I have become closer to them.

title: ~하려는 뜻이다 [haryeoneun tteushida] (Intend to)
short_explanation: This is used to express an intention or plan to do something in the future.
long_explanation: '~하려는 뜻이다 [haryeoneun tteushida]' is a grammatical construction used to indicate the speaker's intention or plan to do something. It is usually expressed using the verb stem + 려는 뜻이다. In English, it is equivalent to 'intend to' or 'plan to', and it is used to express future goals or plans.

examples.kr: 저는 내일 친구를 만나려는 뜻이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naeil chingureul mannaryeoneun tteushieyo.
examples.en: I intend to meet my friend tomorrow.

examples.kr: 우리 팀은 이번 경기에서 이기려는 뜻이에요.
examples.romaji: Uri timeun ibeon gyeonggieseo igiryeoneun tteushieyo.
examples.en: Our team intends to win in this game.

examples.kr: 나는 어르신들을 돕려는 뜻이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoreusindeureul dobryeoneun tteushieyo.
examples.en: I intend to help the elderly.

examples.kr: 그는 영어를 배우려는 뜻이다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun yeongeoreul baeuryeoneun tteushida.
examples.en: He intends to learn English.

title: ~하면 ~하다 [hamyeon hada] (If ~ then)
short_explanation: Used to describe conditional statements or a sequence of events; 'if ~ then'.
long_explanation: '~하면 ~하다 [hamyeon hada]' is used in Korean to link a condition with its result or subsequent action. When the action or condition in the first clause occurs, the second clause follows as a consequence. It is similar to the English 'if ~ then' structure and can be used to express hypothetical scenarios or sequential events.
formation: Verb/Adjective in dictionary form + 면 + Verb/Adjective in dictionary form + 다

examples.kr: 복습하면 시험을 잘 볼 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Bokseup hamyeon siheomeul jal bol su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you review, you will be able to do well on the exam.

examples.kr: 내일 날씨가 좋으면 나는 공원에 갈 거야.
examples.romaji: Naeil nalssiga joheumyeon naneun gongwon-e gal geoya.
examples.en: If the weather is good tomorrow, I will go to the park.

examples.kr: 이 케이크를 많이 먹으면 살이 찔 거예요.
examples.romaji: I keikeureul mani meogeumyeon sali jjil geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you eat a lot of this cake, you will gain weight.

examples.kr: 우리가 먼저 출발하면 시간에 맞출 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Uriga meonjeo chulbalhamyeon sigane matjul su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: If we depart first, I think we can make it in time.

title: ~할 만하다 [hal manhada] (Worth to)
short_explanation: Loosely translates to 'worth to' or 'deserving of', used to express that something is worthwhile.
long_explanation: The construction '~할 만하다' is used to express the idea that something is worth the effort, time, or cost. The verb that precedes this construction determines the context. It is often translated as 'worth to' or 'deserving of' in English. Generally, it is used when something is considered worthwhile or valuable, and it is not typically used in the negative form.

examples.kr: 이거 보면 진짜 너무 재미있어서 반복해서 볼 만해요, 시간 아깝지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Igeo bomyeon jinjja neomu jaemiisseoseo banbokhaeseo bol manhaeyo, sigan akkapji anhayo.
examples.en: This is so interesting that it’s worth watching over and over; it’s not a waste of time.

examples.kr: 그 영화는 정말로 감동적이어서 꼭 봐야 할 만해요, 한 번 더 보고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwa-neun jeongmallo gamdongjeogieoseo kkok bwaya hal manhaeyo, han beon deo bogo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: That movie is really moving—it’s definitely worth watching, and I want to see it again.

examples.kr: 이 요리는 재료비가 좀 비싸도 만들어 먹을 만해요, 맛이 훌륭해서 매우 만족스럽습니다.
examples.romaji: I yorineun jaeryobiga jom bissado mandeuleo meogeul manhaeyo, masi hullyunghaseo maeu manjogseureopseumnida.
examples.en: This dish is worth making even if the ingredients are a bit expensive, because the taste is excellent and very satisfying.

examples.kr: 이 책은 가격이 비싸지만 읽을 만해요, 그 안에 많은 지식이 있어서 돈이 아까워하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I chaeg-eun gagyeogi bissajiman ilgeul manhaeyo, geu ane manheun jisigi isseoseo doni akkawohaji anhayo.
examples.en: This book is worth reading even though it’s expensive, because it contains so much knowledge that the money isn’t wasted.

title: ~할 바에 [hal bae] (Rather than)
short_explanation: Used to express a preference for an alternative action over the one in consideration; 'rather than'.
long_explanation: '~할 바에 [hal bae]' is used in Korean to indicate that, given a choice between two actions, the speaker prefers not to do the action attached to '할 바에'. It emphasizes a preference for a different action over the one being considered. It is often used when expressing a negative alternative or an unfavorable option.

examples.kr: 그런 말을 들을 바에 차라리 아무 말도 듣지 않는 게 낫겠다.
examples.romaji: Geureon mareul deureul bae charari amu maldo deutji anneun ge natgetda.
examples.en: Rather than listening to such words, it would be better not to listen at all.

examples.kr: 혼자 있을 바에 친구와 함께 여행을 가는 것이 더 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Honja issul bae chinguga hamkke yeohaeng-eul ganeun geosi deo joheul geot gat-ayo.
examples.en: Rather than being alone, I think it would be better to travel with a friend.

examples.kr: 그와 싸울 바에 차라리 화해하는 것이 더 낫다.
examples.romaji: Geuwa ssaul bae charari hwahaehaneun geosi deo natda.
examples.en: Rather than fighting with him, it's better to reconcile.

examples.kr: 취업하지 못할 바에 그냥 학교를 계속 다니는 게 나을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Chwieop-haji mothal bae geunyang hakgyoreul gyesok danineun ge na-eul geot gat-ayo.
examples.en: Rather than being unable to find a job, I think it might be better to just keep going to school.

title: ~할 리가 없다 [hal riga eopda] (There's no way that)
short_explanation: Used to express impossibility or disbelief in a certain action or state.
long_explanation: '~할 리가 없다 [hal riga eopda]' is a Korean grammar point used to express the speaker's disbelief or assertion that something is impossible or cannot be the case. It translates to 'there's no way that' in English, signifying that the speaker strongly believes a certain action or situation cannot or will not occur.
formation: Verb (in dictionary form) + 할 리가 없다

examples.kr: 그가 거짓말을 할 리가 없어요, 그는 정직한 사람이니까요.
examples.romaji: Geuga geojitmareul hal riga eopseoyo, geuneun jeongjighan salam-ikka.
examples.en: There's no way he would lie, because he is an honest person.

examples.kr: 지금 그렇게 어두운데 외출할 리가 없어요, 위험하니까요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum geuleohge eodu-unde oechulhal riga eopseoyo, wiheomhanikka.
examples.en: There's no way I'm going out now since it's so dark, because it's dangerous.

examples.kr: 저런 큰 일을 혼자 해낼 리가 없어요, 도와주지 않으면 가능성이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoleon keun il-eul honja haenael riga eopseoyo, dowajujianheumyeon ganeungseong-i eopseoyo.
examples.en: There's no way I can handle such a big task alone; without help, it won't be possible.

examples.kr: 그녀가 나를 싫어할 리가 없어요, 우리는 최고의 친구니까요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga naleul silheohal riga eopseoyo, ulineun choegoui chingunikka.
examples.en: There's no way she would dislike me, because we are the best of friends.

title: ~할 때마다 [hal ttaemada] (Every time when)
short_explanation: Used to indicate repetition; 'every time when' or 'whenever'.
long_explanation: '~할 때마다 [hal ttaemada]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate an action or state that repeatedly happens whenever a certain condition or situation occurs. It conveys a sense of regular occurrence, akin to 'every time when' or 'whenever' in English. It is used to emphasize the consistent and repetitive nature of an action or state in relation to a specific situation.
formation: Verb in dictionary form + 할 때마다

examples.kr: 나는 책을 읽을 때마다 새로운 지식을 얻게 됩니다, 그래서 저는 많이 읽는 것을 좋아합니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaeg-eul ilgeul ttaemada saeroun jisigeul eotge doepnida, geureoseo jeoneun mani ilgneun geoseul joahamnida.
examples.en: Every time I read a book, I gain new knowledge, so I like reading a lot.

examples.kr: 그는 연습할 때마다 더 나은 성과를 얻을 수 있습니다, 그는 항상 최선을 다하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun yeonseubhal ttaemada deo naeun seonggwaleul eoteul su issseumnida, geuneun hangsang choeseoneul dahago issseumnida.
examples.en: Every time he practices, he can achieve better results; he is always doing his best.

examples.kr: 오빠를 만날 때마다 로맨틱한 영화를 보러 갑니다, 그래서 저희는 항상 행복합니다.
examples.romaji: Oppareul mannal ttaemada romaentikhan yeonghwareul boreo gamnida, geureoseo jeohui neun hangsang haengbokhamnida.
examples.en: Every time I meet my older brother, we go to watch a romantic movie, so we are always happy.

examples.kr: 우리는 축구를 할 때마다 친구들과 많은 재미를 느낍니다, 우리는 축구를 정말 좋아합니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun chukgureul hal ttaemada chingudeulgwa manheun jaemireul neukkimnida, urineun chukgureul jeongmal joahamnida.
examples.en: Every time we play soccer, we have a lot of fun with our friends; we really love soccer.

title: ~할 힘이 없다 [hal himi eopda] (Don't have the strength/energy to)
short_explanation: This phrase is used to express that one doesn't have the strength or energy to do something.
long_explanation: The phrase '~할 힘이 없다 [hal himi eopda]' is commonly used in Korean to demonstrate the absence of capability, energy, or strength to perform a particular action. It is typically used to express physical or emotional fatigue that hinders one's ability to carry out a task.

examples.kr: 일이 너무 많아서 더 이상 할 힘이 없어요. 하루에 적어도 8시간은 쉬어야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Il-i neomu manhaseo deo isang hal himi eopseoyo. Haru-e jeogeodo 8sigan-eun swieoya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I have so much work that I don’t have the strength to do any more. I think I need to rest at least 8 hours a day.

examples.kr: 어제 밤에 잠을 거의 못 잤어서 오늘은 더 이상 일할 힘이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje bam-e jam-eul geoi mos jass-eoseo oneul-eun deo isang ilhal himi eopseoyo.
examples.en: I barely slept last night, so I don’t have the strength to work today.

examples.kr: 일주일 동안 운동을 하루도 빠트리지 않고 했더니 몸이 아파서 더 이상 운동할 힘이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Ilju-il dong-an undong-eul harudo ppatteuriji anko haessdeoni mom-i apaseo deo isang undonghal himi eopseoyo.
examples.en: I exercised every day for a week, and now my body is so sore that I don’t have the strength to exercise anymore.

examples.kr: 이번 주 동안 시험 공부에 너무 힘들게 해서 더 이상 공부할 힘이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon ju dong-an siheom gongbu-e neomu himdeulge haeseo deo isang gongbureul himi eopseoyo.
examples.en: I studied so hard for the exams this week that I don’t have the strength to study any further.

title: ~할 것 같다 [hal geot gatda] (Seems like, feels like)
short_explanation: Used to express prediction, expectation, or intuition; 'seems like', 'feels like'.
long_explanation: '~할 것 같다 [hal geot gatda]' is a sentence-ending expression in Korean used to predict or express an expectation or feeling about a future event. The speaker uses this form to share an opinion or intuition based on observations. It is translated as 'seems like' or 'feels like' in English.

examples.kr: 오늘은 비가 올 것 같아, 위에 먹구름이 가득 끼었어.
examples.romaji: Oneureun biga ol geot gata, wi-e meokgureum-i gadeuk kkyeosseo.
examples.en: It seems like it will rain today; the sky is filled with dark clouds.

examples.kr: 그녀가 너를 좋아할 것 같아, 항상 너에게 웃음짓는 걸 보니까.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga neoreul joahal geot gata, hangsang neoege useumjineun geol bonikka.
examples.en: It seems like she likes you—she always smiles at you.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 어려울 것 같아, 범위가 너무 넓어.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi eoryeoul geot gata, beomwigwa neomu neolbeo.
examples.en: It seems like tomorrow’s test will be difficult because the scope is too wide.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 프로젝트를 성공할 것 같아, 모두가 열심히 준비하고 있으니까.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon peurojekteureul seonggonghal geot gata, moduga yeolsimhi junbihago isseunikka.
examples.en: I think this project will be successful since everyone is preparing so hard.

title: ~할 것이다 [hal geosida] (Will)
short_explanation: Used to express that an event will occur in the future.
long_explanation: '~할 것이다 [hal geosida]' is a future tense marker in Korean. It is attached to the end of a verb to indicate that something is going to or will happen. It can also express the speaker’s wish, intention, or prediction regarding a future event.

examples.kr: 눈이 계속 이렇게 오면 학교가 내일은 문을 닫을 것이다.
examples.romaji: Nuni gyesok ireohge omyeon hakgyoga naeireun muneul dateul geosida.
examples.en: If it keeps snowing like this, the school will close tomorrow.

examples.kr: 체육대회가 다가오므로 우리들은 더 열심히 연습할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Cheyukdaehoe-ga dagao-myeoseo urideureun deo yeolsimhi yeonseuphal geosida.
examples.en: As the sports meet approaches, we will practice harder.

examples.kr: 지난 학기보다 이번 학기 성적이 더 좋을 것이다.
examples.romaji: Jinan hakgiboda ibeon hakgi seongjeogi deo joheul geosida.
examples.en: This semester's grades will be better than last semester's.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 별이 많이 보일 것이다.
examples.romaji: Oneul bame byeoli mani boil geosida.
examples.en: A lot of stars will be visible tonight.

title: ~할 줄 알다 [hal jul alda] (Know how to)
short_explanation: Used to express 'know how to' or 'the ability to do something'.
long_explanation: '~할 줄 알다 [hal jul alda]' is a grammatical expression used to convey the ability or knowledge of how to do something. When attached to a verb stem, it indicates that someone knows how to perform that action. It is often used in conversation to ask or assert one’s ability.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 얼마나 잘하냐고요? 음, 가장 기본적인 대화를 할 줄 알아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul eolmana jalhanyagoyo? Eum, gajang gibonjeogin daehwareul hal jul alayo.
examples.en: How well do I know Korean? Well, I know how to have even the most basic conversations.

examples.kr: 우리 아이가 피아노를 칠 줄 알아서, 항상 연주를 들려줄 때가 가장 행복해요.
examples.romaji: Uri aiga piano-reul chil jul alaseo, hangsang yeonjureul deullyeojul ttaega gajang haengbokhaeyo.
examples.en: Our child knows how to play the piano, so I'm happiest when they perform for us.

examples.kr: 너는 어떻게 요리를 할 줄 알았어? 식사는 정말 맛있었어.
examples.romaji: Neoneun eotteoke yorireul hal jul alatseo? Siksaneun jeongmal masisseosseo.
examples.en: How did you learn to cook? The meal was really delicious.

examples.kr: 저는 컴퓨터 프로그래밍을 할 줄 알아요, 그래서 여러 가지 문제를 해결할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keompyuteo peurogeuraeming-eul hal jul alayo, geuraeseo yeoreo gaji munjeleul haegyeolhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I know how to do computer programming, so I can solve various problems.

title: ~할지라도 [haljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'even if', 'even though', or 'regardless of'.
long_explanation: '~할지라도 [haljirado]' is a conjugation form used to express that, even if a certain condition or circumstance exists, the outcome in the second clause remains true. It is often used in hypothetical or speculative situations.
formation: Verb in future tense form + 지라도

examples.kr: 얼마나 바빠서 시간이 없을지라도, 매일 운동하는 것이 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Eolmana bappaseo sigani eopseuljirado, maeil undonghaneun geozi jungyohaeyo.
examples.en: Even if you are so busy that you have no time, exercising every day is important.

examples.kr: 맛이 얼마나 좋을지라도, 건강에 해로운 음식은 피해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Masi eolmana joheuljirado, geongange haeroun eumsigeun pihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: Even if something tastes really good, you must avoid food that is harmful to your health.

examples.kr: 어려울지라도, 계속 연습하면 결국에는 성공할 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Eoryeouljirado, gyesok yeonseuphamyeon gyeolgugeneun seonggonghal su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if it’s difficult, if you keep practicing, you will eventually succeed.

examples.kr: 비가 오고 있을지라도, 오늘은 외출할 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Biga ogo isseuljirado, oneuleun oechulhal gyehoegieyo.
examples.en: Even if it’s raining, I plan to go out today.

title: ~할지언정 [haljieonjeong] (Regardless of whether)
short_explanation: Used to express 'regardless of whether', 'no matter what', or 'even if'. It shows that even if a condition exists, it will not affect the speaker's decision or action.
long_explanation: '~할지언정 [haljieonjeong]' is used to indicate that regardless of a certain condition or situation in the first clause, the outcome or decision in the main clause remains unchanged. It is similar to 'whether or not' or 'no matter what' in English.

examples.kr: 문제가 어렵다 할지언정 끝까지 풀어 볼 것이다.
examples.romaji: Munjega eoryeopda haljieonjeong kkeutkkaji pureo bol geosida.
examples.en: Regardless of whether the problem is difficult, I will try to solve it to the end.

examples.kr: 그녀가 나를 싫어한다 할지언정 나는 그녀를 계속 사랑할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nareul silheohanda haljieonjeong naneun geunyeoreul gyesok saranghal geosida.
examples.en: Regardless of whether she dislikes me, I will continue to love her.

examples.kr: 날씨가 차갑다 할지언정 우리는 계속 걸어가야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chagapda haljieonjeong urineun gyesok georeogaya hamnida.
examples.en: Regardless of whether the weather is cold, we have to keep walking.

examples.kr: 시험이 어렵다 할지언정 저는 공부를 계속해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi eoryeopda haljieonjeong jeoneun gongbureul gyesokhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: Regardless of whether the exam is difficult, I have to keep studying.

title: ~함에 있어 [hame isseo] (In terms of)
short_explanation: This pattern is used to indicate 'in terms of', 'when it comes to', or 'with respect to'.
long_explanation: '~함에 있어' is used when explaining a standard or point of view on which a judgment is made. It is equivalent to 'in terms of', 'when it comes to', or 'in the context of' in English. This form is often used in sentences that express opinions or subjective views from a particular perspective.

examples.kr: 식량 생산함에 있어 아직 많은 문제점이 있습니다, 그러므로 우리는 새로운 변화의 필요성을 느껴야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Sigryang saengsan-ham-e iss-eo ajig manheun munjejeom-i issseumnida, geuleomulo ulineun saeloun byeonhwa-ui pil-yoseong-eul neuggyeoya hamnida.
examples.en: In terms of food production, there are still many problems; therefore, we need to recognize the need for new changes.

examples.kr: 사랑함에 있어 솔직함이 가장 중요한 요소 중 하나라고 생각합니다.
examples.romaji: Salang-ham-e iss-eo soljigham-i gajang jung-yohan yoso jung hanalago saenggakhabnida.
examples.en: In terms of love, I believe honesty is one of the most important factors.

examples.kr: 환경보호함에 있어 각 사람의 작은 노력이 큰 변화를 가져옵니다.
examples.romaji: Hwangyeong boho-ham-e iss-eo gak salam-ui jag-eun nolyeog-i keun byeonhwa leul gajyeo-omnida.
examples.en: In terms of environmental protection, each person's small effort brings about great change.

examples.kr: 팀워크함에 있어서는 그녀가 우리 팀에서 가장 중요한 사람입니다.
examples.romaji: Timweokeu-ham-e iss-eoseoneun geunyeoga uli tim-eseo gajang jung-yohan salam-ibnida.
examples.en: In terms of teamwork, she is the most important person on our team.

title: ~해 보이다 [hae boida] (Look/seem to be)
short_explanation: Used to express an observation or opinion about how someone or something appears or seems.
long_explanation: '~해 보이다 [hae boida]' is used in Korean to describe how someone or something appears based on personal observation. It combines an adjective or descriptive verb (in dictionary form) with 보이다 to express a subjective judgment—equivalent to 'look/seem to be' in English.

examples.kr: 그 여자는 정말 행복해 보이던데요, 항상 웃는 얼굴로 사람들을 인사했어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeojaneun jeongmal haengbokhae boiddeondeyo, hangsang utneun eolgullo saramdeureul insahayeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: That woman seemed really happy; she always greeted people with a smiling face.

examples.kr: 이 음식은 맛있어 보여서 바로 주문했어요.
examples.romaji: I eumsik-eun masisseo boyeoseo baro jumunhaesseoyo.
examples.en: This food looked delicious, so I ordered it right away.

examples.kr: 그의 표정으로 봐서는 정말로 슬픈 일이 생긴 것 같아 보였어요.
examples.romaji: Geuui pyojeong-eulo bwaseoneun jeongmallo seulpeun il-i saeng-gin geot gat-a boyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Judging by his expression, it seemed like something really sad had happened.

examples.kr: 벚꽃이 만발한 이 공원은 진짜 아름다워 보여요.
examples.romaji: Beotkkot-i manbalhan i gong-woneun jinjja areumdawo boyeoyo.
examples.en: This park, full of blooming cherry blossoms, looks truly beautiful.
